DIV1.P: THE VVHOLE BOOKE OF PSALMES Faithfully TRANSLATED into ENGLISH Metre.
Whereunto is prefixed a discourse de∣claring not only the lawfullnes, but also the necessity of the heavenly Ordinance of singing Scripture Psalmes in the Churches of God.

Q.P: Let the word of God dwell plenteously in you, in all wisdome, teaching and exhort∣ing one another in Psalmes, Himnes, and spirituall Songs, singing to the Lord with grace in your hearts.
any be afflicted, let him pray, and if any be merry let him sing psalmes.

DIV1.P: Imprinted 1640

DIV1.HEAD: The Preface.
DIV1.P: THe singing of Psalmes, though it nothing but holy harmony, and such is the subtilty of the enemie, of our nature against the Lord, & his our hearts can finde matter of discord in , and crotchets of division in this . -for- There have been three questiō stirrīg cōcerning singing. First▪ are to be sung in churches? whether scripture psalmes, or the psalmes the gifts of godly men in every age of the Secondly, if scripture psalmes, whet owne words, or in such meter as english wont to run in? Thirdly· by whom are they o be sung? whether by the whole churches togethr with their voices? or by one man singing alōe ad the rest joynīg in silēce, & in the close sayīg amen.

Touching the first, certainly the singing of Da∣vids psalmes was an acceptable worship of God, not only in his owe, but in succeeding tie▪ as in Solomons time 2 Chron. 5.13. in time 2 chron. 20.31. in Ez time Eza 3.10, 11. and the text is evint in Hezekiahs time they are commanded to sing praise in the words of David and Asaph, 2 chron. 29, 30. which one place may serve to resolve two of the questions (the first and the last) at once▪ for this commandement was it ceri∣moniall
or morall? some things in it ideed were cerimoniall, as their musicall instruments &c but what cerimony was there in singing prayse with the wods of David and Asaph? what if Da∣vid was a typeof Christ, was Asaph also? was every thing of David typicall? are his words (which are of morall, universall, and perpetuall authority in all nations and ages) are they typi∣call? what type can be imagined in making use of his songs to prayse the Lord? If they were ty∣picall bcause the cerimony of musicall instru∣ments was joyned with them, then their prayers were alsotypicall, because they had that ceremo∣ny of incense admixt with them: but wee know that prayer then was a morall duty, notwithstand∣ing the incense; and soe singing those psalmes not∣withstanding their musicall instruments. Beside, that which was typicall (as that they were sung wih musicall instruments, by the twenty-foure orders of Priests and Levites. 1 chron 25.9.) must have the morall and spirituall accomlishment in the new Testament, in all the Churches of the Saints principally, who are made kings & priests Reu. 1.6. and are the first fruits unto God. Reu. 1 4. as the Levites were Num. 3.45. with hearts & lippes, in stead of musicall instruments, to prayse the Lord; who are set forth (as some iudiciously thinke) Reu. 4.4. by twēty foure Elders, in the ripe age of the Church, Gal. 4.1, 2, 3. answering to the twenty foure order of Priests and Levites 1 chron. 25.9. Therefore not some select
members, but the whole Church is to teach one another in all the special singing of Davids psalmes, some being called by the th : psalms, some Hymns some : spirituall songs. oe that if the singing Davids psalmes be a morall duty & ther∣fore perpetuall; then wee under the new Testamēt are bound to sing them as well as they under the old: and if wee are expresly commanded to sing Psalmes, Hymnes, and spirituall songs, then either wee must sing Davids psalmes, or else may affirm they are not spirituall songs: which being penned by an extraordīay gift of the Spirit, for the sak especially of Gods spirtuall Israell; not to be read and preached only (as other parts of holy writ) but to be sung also, they are therefore most spirituall, and still to be sung of all the Israell of God: and verily as their sin is exceeding great, who will allow Davids psalmes (as other scrip∣tures) to be read in churches (which is one end) but not to be preached also, (which is another end foe their sin is crying before God, who will al∣low them to be read and preached, but seeke o deprive the Lord of the glory of the third of them, which is to sing them in christian obj. 1 If it be sayd hat the Saints in the Church did compile spirituall songs owne inditing, and sing them before the 1 Cor. 14, 15, 16.

Ans. We answer first, that those Saints copiled these spirituall songs by the extraordinary gifts of
the spirit (common in those dayes) whereby they were inabled to praise the Lord in strange tongu∣es, wherin learned Paras proves those psalme were uttered, in his Commēt on that place ers 14 which extraordinary gifts, if they were still in the Churches, wee should allow them the like liberty now. Secondly, suppose those psalmes were sung by an ordinary gift (which wee suppose cannot be victed) doth it therefore follow that they did no, & that we ought not to sing Davids psalmes? must the ordinary gifts of a private man quench the spirit still speaking to us by the extraordin¦ry gifts of his servant David? there is not the lst foot-step of example, or precept, or colour son for such a bold practise.
obj. 2. Ministers are allowed to pray conceived rayers, and why not to sing conceived psalmes? must wee not sing in the spirit as well as pray in the spirit?

Ans. First because every good minister hath not a gift of spirituall poetry to compose extempora∣ry psalmes as he hath of prayer. Secondly. Sup¦pose he had, yet seeing psalmes are to be sung by a oynt consent and harmony of all the Church in heart and voyce (as we shall prove) this cannot be done except he that composeth a psalme, bring¦th into the Church set formes of psalmes of his one invētion; for which wee finde no warrant or president in any ordinary officers of the Church houghout the sciptures. Thirdly. Because the book of psalmes is so compleat a System of
psalmes, which the Holy-Ghost himselfe in wisdoe hath made to suit all the conditions, necessityes, temptations, affections, &c. of men in all ages; (as most of all our interpreters on the psalmes have fully and prticularly cleare where fore by this the Lord seemeth to stoppeth mens mouths and mindes ordinarily to compile or sing any other psames (under colour that the ocasions and conditions of the Church are new) &c. for the publick use of the Church, seing, let our condition be what it will, the Lord himselfe hath supplyed us with farre better; and therefore in Hezekiahs time, though doubtlesse there were among them those which had extraoridnary gifts to compile new songs on those new ocasions, as Isaiah and Micah &c. yet wee read that they are commanded to sing in the words of David and Asaph, which were ordinarily to be used in the publick worship of God: and wee doubt not but those that are wise will easily see; that those set formes of psalmes of Gods owne appoynt∣ment not of mans conceived gift or humane imposition were sung in the Spirit by those ho∣ly Levites, as well as their prayers were in the spirit which themselves conceived, the Lord not then binding them therin to any set formes; and shall set formes of psalmes appoynted of God not be sung in the spirit no, which others did then?

Queston. But why may not one cōpose a psalme & sing it alone with a loud voice & the rst joyne
with him in silence and in the end say Amen?

Ans. If such a practise was found in the Church of Corith, when any had a psalme suggested by an extraordinary gift; yet in singing ordinary psalmes the whole Church is to ioyne together in heart and voyce to prayse the Lord. -for- First. Davids psalmes as hath beene shewed, were sung in heart and voyce together by the twenty foure orders of the musicians of the Tem¦ple, who typed out the twenty foure Elders all the members especially of christian Churches R 5.. who are made Kings and Priests to God to prayse him as they did: for if there were any other oder of singing Choristers beside the body of the people to succeed those, the Lord would doubtlesse have given direction in the gospell for their quallification, election, maintainance &c. as he did for the musicians of the Temple, and as his faithfullnes hath done for all other church officers in the new Testament. Secondly. Others beside the Levites (the chiefe Singers) in the ewish Church did also sing the Lords songs; else why are they commanded fre∣quently to sing: as in ps. 100, 1, 2, 3. ps 95, 1, 2, 3. ps. 102. title. with vers 18. & Ex. 15.1. not only Moses but all Israell sang that song, they spake saying (as it is in the orig.) all as well as Moses, the women also as well as the men. v. 20 21. and deut. 32. (whereto some thike, Iohn had refer∣ence as well as to Ex. 15.1. when he brings in the protestant Churches getting the victory over the
Beast with harps in their hands and singing the song of Moses. Reu, 15.3.) this song Moses is commanded not only to put it into their hearts butinto their mouths also: deut. 31.19. which argues, they were with their mouths to sing i. to∣gether as well as with their hearts.

Thirdly. Isiah foretells in the dayes of the new-Testament that Gods watchmen and desolate lost soules, (signified by wast places) should with their voices sing together, Isa. 52.8, 9. and Reu- 7.9, 10. the song of the Lamb was by many to∣gether, and the Apostle expresly commands the singing of Psalmes, Himnes, &c. not to any se∣lect christians, but to the whole Church Eph. 5.19 coll. 3.16. Paule & Silas sang together in private Acts. 16.25. and must the publick heare ōly one man sing? to all these wee may adde the practise of the primitive Churches; the testimony of an∣cint and holy Basil is in stead of many Epist. 63 When one of us (saith he) hath begun a psalme, the rest of us set in to sing with him, all of us with one heart and one voyce; and this saith he is the common practise of the Churches in Egypt, Lybi, Thebes, Palestina, Syria and those that dwell on Euphrates, and generally every where, where singing of psalmes is of any account. To the sme purpose also Eusebius gives witnes, Ecls. Hst. lib. 2. cap. 17. The objections made against this doe most of them plead against joyn∣ing to sing i heart as well as in voyce, as that by this meanes othrs out of the Curch will sing
as also that wee are not alway in a sutable estte to the matter sung, & likewise that all cannot sng with understanding; shall not therefore all that have understanding ioyne in heart and voyce to∣gether? are not all the creatures in heaven, earth, seas: men, beasts, fishes, foules &c. commanded to praise the Lord, and yet none of these but men, and godly men too, can doe it with spirituall understanding?

As for the scruple that some take at the trans∣latiō of the book of psalmes into meeer, because Davids psalmes were sung in his owne words without meeter: wee answer- First· There are many verses together in several psalmes of David which run in rithmes (as those that know the heb∣rew and as Buxtorf shews Thesau. pa. 62.) which shews at least the lawfullnes of singing psalmes in english rithmes.

Secondly. The psalmes are pened in such verses as are sutable to the poetry of the hebrw Language, and not in the common style of such other bookes of the old Testament as are not poeticall; now no protestant doubteth but that all the bookes of the scripture should by Gods ordinance be extant in the mother tongue of each nation, that they may be understood of all, hence the psalmes are to be translated into our eng∣lish tongue; and if in our english tongue wee are to sing them, then as all our english songs (accord¦ing to the course of our english poetry) do run in metre, soe ought Davids palmes to be translated
into meeter, that soe wee may sing the Lords songs, as in our engish tongue soe in such verses as are familar to an english eare which are com∣monly metricall: and as it can be no just offence to any good conscience to sing Davids hebrew songs in english words, soe neither to sing his poeticall verses in english poeticall metre: men might as well stumble at singing the hebrew psalmes in our english tunes (and not in the he∣brew tunes) as at singing them in english meeter, (which are our verses) and not in such verses as are generally used by Davi accordig to the po∣etry of the hebrew language: but the truth is, as the Lord hath hid from us the hebrew tunes, lest wee should think our selves bound to imitate them; soe also the course and frame (for the most part) of their hebrew poetry, that wee might not think our slves bound to imitate that, but that every ntion without scruple miht follow as the graver srt of tunes of their owne country songs, soe the graver sort of verses of their owne count∣ry poetry.

Neither let any think, that for the meetre sake wee hae taken liberty or poeticall licence to depart from the true and proper sence of Davids words in the hbrew verses, noe; but it hath beene one part of our religious care and faithfull inavour, to keepe close to the originall text.

As for othr obiections takn from the diffi∣culty of Amsworths tunes, and the corruptions in
our common psalme books, wee hope they are answered in this new edition of psalmes which wee here present to God and his Churches. For although wee have cause to blesse God in many respects for the religious indeavours of the translaters of the psalmes into meetre usually an∣nexed to our Bibles, yet it is not unknowne to the godly learned that they have rather presented a paraphrase then he words of David translat∣ed according to the rule 2 chron. 29.30. and that their addition to the words, detrctions from the words are not seldome and rare, but very fre∣quent and many times needles, (which we sup∣pose would not be approved of if the psalmes were so translated into prose) and that their variations of the sense, and alterations of the sacred text too frequently, may iustly minister matter of offence to them that are able to com∣pare the translation with the text; of which fail∣ings, some iudicious have oft complained, others have been grieved, wherupon it hath bin generally desired, that as wee doe inioye other, soe (if it were the Lords will) wee might inioye this ordinance also in its native puity: wee have therefore done our indeavour to make a plaine and familiar translation of the psalmes and words of Dvid into english metre, and have not soe much as presumed to paraphrase to give the sense of his meaning in other words; we have therefore attended heerin as our chief guide the originall, shing all additions, except such as even the best
tranlators of them in prose supply, avoiding all materiall detractions from words or sence. The word which wee translate and as it is redun∣dant sometime in the Hebrew, soe somtime (though not very often) it hath been left out, and yet not then, if the sence were not faire without it.

As for our translations, wee have with our english Bibles (to which next to the Originall wee have had respect) used the Idioms of our owne tongue in stead of Hebraismes, lest they might seeme english barbarismes. Synonimaes wee use indifferently: as folk for peo∣ple, and Lord for Iehovah, and somtime (though seldome) God for Iehovah; for which (as for some other interpretations of places cited in the new Testament) we have the scriptures authority ps. 14. with 53. Heb. 1.. with psalme 97. Where a phrase is doubtfull wee have followed that which (in our owne apprehensiō) is most genu¦ine & edifying:

Somtime wee have contracted, somtime dilated the same hebrew word, both for the sence and the verse sake: which dilatation wee conceive to be no paraphrasticall addition no more then the contraction of a true and full translation to be any unfaithfull detraction or di∣minution: as when wee dilate who healeth and say he it is who healeth; soe when wee contract, those that stand in awe of God and say Gods fearers.

Lastly. Because some hebrew words have a
more full and emphaticall signification then any one english word can or doth somtime expresse, hence wee have done that somtime which faith∣full translators may doe, viz. not only to translate the word but the emphasis of it; as mighty God, for God. humbly blesse for blesse; rise to stand, psalm 1. for stand truth and faithfullnes for truth. Howbeit, for the verse sake wee doe not alway thus, yet wee ren∣der the word truly though not fully; as when wee somtime say reioyce for shout for ioye.

As for all other changes of numbers, tenses, and characters of speech, they are such as ither the hebrew will, uforcedly beare, or our english forceably calls for, or they no way change the sence; and such are printed usually in an other character.

If therefore the verses are not alwayes so smooth and elegant as some may desire or expect; let them consider that Gos Altar needs not our pollishings: Ex. 20. for wee have respected rather a plaine transla∣tion, then to smooth ou verses with the sweetnes of any paraphrase, and soe have attendd Conscience rather then Elegance, fidelity rather then poetry, in translating the hebrew words into english language, and Davids poetry into english meerre;
that soe wee may sing in Sion the Lords songs of praye according to his owne will; untill hee take us from hence, and wip away all our teares, & bid us enter into our masters ioye to sing eternall Halleluiahs.

DIV2.HEAD: PSALME I
DIV2.L: O Blessed man, that in th'advice
nor stand in sinners way, nor sit
But in the law of Iehovah,
and in his law doth mditate,
by day and eke by night.
And he shall be like to a tree
that in his season yeilds his fruit,
And all he doth, shall prosper well,
but they are like vnto the chaffe,
which winde drives to and fro.
rise to stand in the doome,
nor shall the sinners with the just,
For of the righteous men, the Lord
but the way of vngodly men,

DIV2.HEAD: PSALM II
DIV2.L: Kings of the earth doe set themselves,
with one consent against the Lord,
Let us asunder break their bands,
their cords bee from us throwne▪
Who sits in heav'n shall laugh; the lord
will mock them; then will he
Speak to them in his ire, and wrath:
But I annoynted have my King
God spake to me, thou art my Son:
Aske thou of me, and I will give
and of the earth thou shalt possesse
thou shalt them break as Potters sherds
And now yee Kings be wise, be learn'd
Serve yee the lord with reverece,
Kisse yee the Sonne, lest he be wroth,
and yee fall in the way.
when his wrath quickly burnes, oh blest?
are all that on him stay.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 3 1 A psalme of David when he fled from the face of Absalom his Sonne.
DIV2.L: O Lord, how many are my foes?
how many up against me stand?
Many say to my soule noe helpe
in God for him at any hand.
But thou ord art my shield, my gory
with voyce to God I cal'd, who from
I layd me downe, I slept, I wakt,
for Ihovah did me up beare:
People that set against me rod,
ten thousand of them I'le not feare.
Arise o Lord, sve me my God,
for all mine enimies thou hast stroke
of the ungodly thou hast broke.
thy blessing is, and let it be

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 4 To the cheife Mus cian on Neginoth, a psalme of David.
DIV2.L: GOD of my ustice, when I call
thou hast inlrg'd e, sw me grace,
Ye Sonnes of men, my glory turne
to shame how long will you?
how long will ye love vanity,
But know, the Lord doth for himselfe
the Lord will heare when I to him
Be stirred up, but doe not sinne,
within your heart upon your bed;
Many there be that say o who,
will cause us good to see:
the light, Lord, of thy countenance
Thou hast put gladnesse in my heart,
their corne, and also their new wine,
In peace with him I will lye downe,
and take my sleepe will I:
For thou Lord mak'st me dwell alone

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 5 1 To the cheife Musiian upon Nehiloth, a pslme of David.
DIV2.L: Heare thou my words and understand
My King, my God, attend the voyce
of my cry: for to thee I pray.
At morn Iehovah, thou shalt heare
my voyce: to thee I will addresse
at morn, I will looke up. For thou
art not a God lov'st wickednesse
neither shall evil with thee dwell.
Vaine glorious fooles before thine eyes
shall never stand: for thou hatest
the lord will make to be abhor'd
the man deceitfull, and of blood.
But I will come into thine house
and will in feare of thee bow downe,
Lead me forth in thy rightousnes,
O Iehovah doe thou thy wayes
make straight, and plaine, before mine eyes
For there no truth is in his mouth,
their tongue is bent to flatteries.
O God make thou them desolate
from their owne plos let them fall far,
cast them out in their heapes of sinnes,
for they against thee Rebells are.
And all that trust in thee shll joy,
and thou shalt them protect: & they
tht love thy name shall jo in thee.
a blessing on the rightous one:
and wilt him crowne as with a shield,

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 6 To the chief Muician on Neginoth upon - Sheminith, a psalme of Dvi.
DIV2.L: LORD in thy wrath rebuke me not,
nor in thy hot wrath chasten me
Pitty me Lord, for I am weak,
Lord heale me, for my bones vext be.
Also my soule is troubled sore:
how long Lord wilt thou me forske?
Returne o Lord, my soule release:
o save me for thy mercy sake.
In death no mem'ry is of thee
and who hll prayse thee in the grave?
I faint with groanes, all night my bed
swims, I with ters my couch wash have.
mine eye with grief is dime and old:
Bu no deprt awy fom me,
for Iehovh ev'n no hath heard
the voyce of these eepig tares.
Let all mine enimies be asham'd
nd greatly troubled let them be:
yea let them be returned back,

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 7 Shiggajon of David which he sāg to Iehovah upō the words of Cush the Benjamite.
DIV2.L: O LORD my God in thee
save and deliver me from all
I est like a Lion hee
if this thing done have I:
if so tere be within my hands
the man with me at peace,
and take, and tread to clay
my life: and honor in the dust
be thou lift up, & wake to me,
and for the same doe thou returne,
The Lord shall judge the folke;
for thou who art the righteous God▪
For God my sheild, the right
The God that doth the rightous judge,
his sword he shrp will whet:
his bow he bended hath, and he
but shll bring forth a lye.
But fall'n he is into the ditch,
shall on his head turn down▪
and I will sig unto the name

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 8 To the chiefe Musician upon Gittith. a psalme of David.
DIV2.L: O ORD our God in all the earth
out of the mouth of sucking babes.
that thou mightst still the enemy,
when I thy figers work, thy Heav'ns,
which thou hast set. What's wretched man,
or what's the Son of man, that thus
For next to Agells, thou hast him
and hast with glory crowned him,
And on thy works hast given him,
All hast thou put under his feet;
and beasts of field. Foules of the ayre▪
and all that passe through paths of seas.
is thy name through the world?

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 9 To the chiefe Musician upon Muth-Labben a psalme of David

LG.L: LORD I'le the prayse, with all my heart;
thy wonders all proclaime.
I will be glad and joy in thee;
most high, I'le sing thy name.
In turning back my foes, they'le fall
and perish at thy sight.
For thou maintaines my right, & cause:
In throne sits judging right.
Thou t' heathen checkst, & th'wicked stroyd;
their names raz'd ever aye.
Thy ruines, foe, for aye are done;
thou madst their townes decaye;
their memory with them is lost.
Yet ever sits the Lord:
is throne to judgement he prepares.
With right he'l judge the world:
he to the folke shall minister
judgement in uprightnesse.
The Lord is for th'oprest a fort:
a fort in times of stresse.
Who knowe thy name, will trust in the:
nor dost thou, Lord forsake,
them that the seek. Psalmes, to the Lord
that dwells in Sion, make:
declare among the folk his works.
For blood when he doth seeke,
he them remembers: nor forgets
the crying of the meeke.
Iehovah, mercy on me have,
from them that doe me hate
marke mine afflictions that arise,
thou lift'st me from deaths-gate.
That I may tell in the gates of
the Daughter of Sion,
thy prayses all. and may rejoyce
in thy salvation.
The heathen are sunk downe into
the pit that they had made:
their owne foot taken is ith'net
which privily they layd.
By judgement which he executes
Iehovah is made knowe:
the wicked's snar'd in's owe hand work.
deepe meditation.
The wiced shall be turn'd to hell,
all ands that God forget.
Forgot the neey shall e're be:
poores hope e'r faild him yet.
Arise, o Lord, lest men prevaile,
judge t' heathen in thy sight.
That they may know they b but men,
the nations Lord affright. Selah
WHy standst thou Lord a far? why hyd'st
thy selfe in times of streight?
In pride the wickd persecutes
the poore afflicted wight:
snare them in their contrived plots.
For of his hearts desire
the wicked boasts, and covetous
blesseth, stirring Gods ire.
The wicked one by reason of
his countennces pride
will not seek after Go: not Go
so all his thoughts abide.
his wayes doe lwayes bring forth griefe▪
on high thy jugements bee
above his fight: pressing foes
puffe at them all will hee.
Within his heart he thus hath sayd,
I move shall not bee:
fro aye to aye because I am
not in adversitie
His mouth with cusing filled is,
deceits, an fallacy:
under his tongue perversnes is,
also iniquiy.
In the ose places of the townes
he sits, in secret dens
he slays the harmlesse: 'gainst the pooe
slyly his eyes downe bends.
He closely lurks as lion lurks
in den, the poore to catch
he lurks, & trapping them in 's net
th' afflicted poore doth snatch.
Downe doth he crowtch, & to the dust
humbly he bowes with-all:
that so a multitude of poore
in his strong pawes may fall.
He saith in heart, God hath forgot:
he hides his face away,
so that he will not see this thing
unto eternall aye.
Iehovah rise thou up, o God
lift thou thine hand on hy,
let not the meek afflicted one
be out of memory.
Wherefore doth the ungodly man
contemne th' almighty one?
he in his heart saith, thou wilt not
make inquisition.
Thou seest, for thou markst wrong, & spight,
with thy hand to repay:
the poore leavs it to thee, thou art
of fatherlesse the stay.
Break thou the arme of the wicked,
and of the evil one.
search thou out his impiety,
untill thou findest none.
Iehovah king for ever is,
and to eternall aye:
out of his land the heathen folke
are perished away.
The meeke afflicted-mans desire
Iehovah, thou dost heare:
thou firmly dost prepare their heart,
thou makst attent thine eare.
To judge the fatherlesse & poore:
that ad no more he may
sorrowfull man out of the land
with terror to dismay.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 11 To the chiefe Musician a psalme of David.
DIV2.L: I In the Lord do trust, how then
to my soule doe ye say,
as doth a litle bird unto
For loe, the wicked bend their bow,
on string; to shoot in dark at them
as for the man that righteous is,
The Lor in's holy temple is,
is eyes will view, and his eye lis
will prove the Sonnes of men.
ev'n him the Lord will prove;
his soule the wicked hates, & him
Snares, fire, & brimstone he will raine,
and burning tempest; of their cup

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 12 To the chiefe Musician upon Sheminth a psalme of David.
DIV2.L: HElpe Lord: for godly men doe cease:
Each to his freind speaks vanity;
and with a double heart they speake.
shall cut them of, with every tongue
Thus have they sayd, we with our tongue,
are not our lips our owne for Lord
Thus saith the Lord, for sighs of them
I'le now arise, from such as puffe,
will set him safe at rest.
Pure are the words the Lord doth speak:
Thou shlt them keep, o Lord, thou shalt
The wicked men on evry side
when as the vilest sons of men

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 13 To the chiefe Musician: a psalme of David.
DIV2.L: how long wilt thou thy countenance
in my heart dayly? o're me set
how long shall be my foe?
the sleepe of death doe take.
Lest my foe say, I have.
those ho doe trouble, doe rejoyce,

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 14 To the chiefe Musician a psalme of Dauid.
DIV2.L: THe foole in's heart saith ther's no God▪
that doth good there is non.
The Lord from heaven looked down
on Sonnes of men: to see,
All are gone back, together they
and there is none doeth good,
noe not s much as one.
that eate my people: they eate bread,
and on God doe not call.
There with a very grievous feare
The counsell yee would make of hi
Who Israels health from Syon gives?
when God shall turne: Iacob shall joye

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 15 A psalme of David.
DIV2.L: IEHOVAH, who shall in thy tent
shall dwell within thy holy mount?
And worketh justice, and speaks truth
in' heart, And with his tongue
he doth not slander, neither doth
And 'gainst his neighbour that doth not
Hee that an abject person is
But he will highly honour them
and changeth not, though to his losse,
i tha he once doe swere.
Nor gives his coyne to vury,
and bribe he doth not take
against the harmelesse▪ he that doth

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 16 Michtam of David
DIV2.L: O Mighty God, preserve thou mee,
for on thee doe I rest.
Thou art my God, vnto the Lord
My goodnes reacheth not to thee.
whome all my joye is on.
They who give gifts to a strange God,
Neither will I into my lips
the names of them take up.
Thou art maintainer of my lot.
To me the lines fal'n bee
in pleasant places: yea, faire is
yea in the nights my reines have mee,
because he is at my right hand
Because thou wilt not leave my soue
nor wilt thou give thine holy one,
Thou wilt shew me the path of life,
before thy face, at thy right hand

LG.L: HArken, o Lord, unto the right,
attend vnto my crye,
give eare vnto my pray'r, that goes
from lips that doe not lye.
From thy face let my judgement come.
thine eyes the right let see.
Thou provst mine heart, thou visitest
by night, and tryest mee.
yet nothing find'st, I have resolvd
my mouth shall not offend.
From mens works: by word of thy lips
I spoylers paths attend.
Stay my feet in thy paths, lest my
steps slip. I cal'd on thee,
for thou wilt heare, God, heare my speec,
incline thine eare to mee.
O thou that sav'st by thy right hand,
thy merveilous-mercyes,
shew vnto them that trust in thee,
from such as 'gainst them rse.
As apple of thine eye mee keep▪
In thy wings shade mee hide.
From wicked who mee wast: my foe
in heart are on each side.
Clos'd in their fat they are: & they
speak with their mouth proudly.
They round us in our stepps: they set
on earth their bow'd downe eye.
His likenes as a lion is,
that greedy is to teare,
in secret places lurking as
hee a young lion were.
Him, in his sight, rise, disappoynt
make him bow downe o Lord,
doe thou my soule deliver from
the wicked one, thy sword,
From mortall men thine hand, o Lord,
from men that mortall are,
and of this passing-world, who hav
within this life their share,
with thy hid treasure furthermore
whose belly thou fillest:
their sonnes are fil'd, & to their babes
of wealth they leave the rest.
In righteousnes, thy favour I
shall very clearely see,
and waking with thine image, I
shall satisfied bee.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 18 To the chiefe Musician, a psalme of Dauid, the srvant of the Lord, who spake the words of this Song, in the day that the Lord deliuered him from the hands of all his enemies, & from the hand of Saule▪ and he Sayde,

LG.L: IL'e dearely love thee, Lord, my strength.
The Lord is my rock, and my towre,
and my deliverer, my God,
I'le trust in him who is my powre,
My shield, & my salvationes-horne,
my high-fort; Who is prayse worthy,
I on the Lord will call, so shall
I bee kept from mine enemye.
Deaths sorrowes mee encompassed,
mee fear'd the floods of ungodlie,
Hells pangs beset me round about,
the snares of death prevented mee.
I in my streights, cal'd on the Lord,
and to my God cry'd: he did heare
from his temple my voyce, my crye,
before him came, unto his eare.
Then th' earth shooke, & quak't, & moūtaines
roots moov'd, & were stird at his ire,
Vp from his nostrils went a smoak,
and from his mouth devouring-fire:
By it the coales inkindled were.
Likewie the heavens he downe-bow'd,
and he descended, & there was
under his feet a gloomy cloud.
And he on cherub rode, and flew;
yea he flew on the wings of winde.
His secret place hee darknes made
his covert that him round confinde,
Dark waters, & thick clouds of skies.
From brightnes, that before him was,
his thickned clouds did passe away,
hayl-stones and coales of fire did passe.
Also Iehovah thundered,
within the heavens, the most high
likewise his angry-voyce did give,
hayl-stones, and coales of fire did fly.
Yea he did out his arrows send,
and bruising he them scattered,
and lightnings hee did multiply,
likewise he them discomfited.
The waters channels then were seene,
and the foundationes of the world
appear'd; at thy rebuke, at blast,
of the breath of thy nostrils Lord.
Hee from above sent hee me took:
e out of waters-great he drew.
Hee from mine enemies-strong, & from
them which me hated did rescue.
For they were mightyer then I.
They mee prevented in the day
of my cloudy calamity;
but for me was the Lord a stay.
And hee me to large place brought forth:
hee sav'd mee, for he did delight
in mee. The Lord rewaded me
according as I did aright,
Accoding to the clenesse of
my hands, he recompenced mee.
For the wayes of the Lord I kept:
nor from my God went wickedlie.
For all his judgements mee before:
nor from me put I his decree.
With him I upright was, and kept
my selfe from mine iniquitie.
The Lord hath recompenced mee,
after my righteousnes therefore:
according to the cleannesse of
my hands that was his eyes before.
With mercifull, thou mercifull,
with upright thou deales uprightly.
With pure thou pure, thou also wilt
with froward turne thy selfe awry.
For thou wilt save th'afflicted folke:
but wilt the lofty looks suppresse.
For thou wilt light my lampe: the Lord▪
my God will lighten my darknesse.
For by thee rann through a troupe,
and by my God leapt o're a wall.
Gods way is perfect: Gods word tryde▪
that trust in him hee's shield to all.
For who is God except the Lord?
or who a rock, our God except?
Its God that girdeth me with strength,
and hee doth make my way perfect.
Like to the hyndes he makes my feet:
and on my high place maks me stand.
Mine armes doe break a bow of brasse;
so well to warre he learnes my hand.
The shield of thy salvation
thou furthermore hast given :
and thy right-hand hath mee upeld,
thy meeknes made mee great to bee.
Vnder me thou makst large my steps.
so that mine anckles did not slyde
My foes pursu'de I, & them caught:
nor turn'd I till they were destroyd.
I wounded them & they could
rise up: under my feet they fell.
Because that thou hast girded mee
with fortitude to the battel▪
Thou hast subdued under mee,
those that did up against me ri.
And my foes necks thou gavest mee,
that I might wast mine enemyes.
They cryde but there was none to save,
to God, yet with no answer meet.
I beat them then as dust i'th winde
and cast them out as dirt i'th str.
And thou from the contentions
hast of the people mee set free;
thou of the hthen mad'st me had▪
people I knew not shall serve mee.
They'le at first hearing me obey:
strangers shall yield themselvs to me.
The strangers shall consume away,
and from their closets frighted bee.
The Lord lives, and blest be my Rok,
let my healths God exated ee.
It's God for m that vegeance works,
and brings dowe pople under mee.
Mee from mine enemies he doth save:
and above those that 'gainst me went,
thou lift'st me up; and thou hast freed
mee from the man that's violent.
I with confession will therefore
unto thee render thanksgiving,
o Lord▪ among the heathen folk;
and to thy name I'le prayss .
He givh great delivera▪
to his King, and doth shew mercy
to his annoynted, to David,
and to his see eernally.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 19 To the chiefe musician a psalme of David.

LG.L: THe heavens doe declare
the majesty of God:
also the firmament shws foth
his and-work abroad.
Day speaks to day, knowledge
night hath to night declar'd.
There neither speach nor language i,
where their voyce is not heard.
Through all the earth their line
is gone forth, & unto
the utmost end of all the world,
their speaches reach also:
Ta berncle hee
in them pitcht for the Sun.
Who Bridegroom like front's chamber goes
glad Giants-race o run.
From heavens utmost end,
his course and compassing;
to ends of it, & from the ea
thereof is hid nothing.
The Lords law perfect is,
the soule converting back:
Gods testimony faithfull is,
makes wise who-wisdome-lack.
The statutes of the Lord,
are right, & glad the heart:
the Lords commandement is pure,
light doth to eyes impart.
Iehovahs feare is cleane,
and doth indur for ever:
the judgements of the Lord ae true,
and righteous altogether.
Then gold, then much fine gold,
more to be prized are,
then hony, & the hony-comb,
sweeter they are by farre.
Also thy servant is
admonished from hence:
and in the keeping of the same
is a full recompence.
Who can his errors know?
from secret faults cleanse mee.
And from presumptuous-sins,
thy servant bee:
Let them not beare the rule
in me, & then shall I
be perfect, and shall cleansed bee
from much iniquity.
Let the words of my mouth,
and the thoughts of my heart,
be pleasing with thee, Lord, my Rock
who my redeemer art.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 20 To the chiefe Musician, a psalme of Dvid.
DIV2.L: IEHOVAH heare thee in the day
the name of the God ofIacob
Send thee help from his holy place:
Minde all thy gifts, thy sacrifice
Grant thee according to thy heart,
And we in the name of our God
Now I know, that Iehovah doth
with saving strength of his right hand
but we the name of Iehovah
They are brought downe & fal'n: but we,
Save Lord, & let the King us heare
when as to him we cry.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 21 To the chiefe Musician a psalme of David.
DIV2.L: Thou of his heart to him
and thou hast not witholden back,
what his lips did require. Selah.
thou on his head of finest gold
to him thou gav'st it free,
even length of days for evermore
Thou makst him with thy countenance
through mercy of the highest one,
thy right hand also shall finde ou
them in times of thine ire:
the Lord will swallow them in's wrath
out of the earth: & their seed from
a wicked plot they have devis'd,
For thou wilt as a butt
thine arrows ready on thy string,
and wee will sing; yea prayse with psalmes▪

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 22 To the chiefe musician upon Aijeleth Shba a psalme of David.

LG.L: MY God, my God, wherefore hast thou
forsaken mee? & why,
art thou so farre from helping mee,
from the words of my cry?
O my God, I doe cry by day,
but mee thou dost not heare;
and eke by night, & unto mee
no quiet rest is there.
Neverthelesse thou holy art,
who constantly dost dwell,
within the thankfull prayses of
thy people Israell.
Our fore-fathers in thee have put
assured confidence:
they trusted have, & thou to them
didst give deliverance.
Vnto thee they did cry aloud,
and were delivered:
in thee they put their confidence,
and were not confounded.
But I a worme, & not a man;
of men an opprobrie,
and also of the people am
despis'd contempuouslie.
All they that doe upon mee look,
a scoffe at mee doe make:
they with the lip doe make a mow,
the head in scorne they shake.
Vpon the Lord he rold himselfe,
let him now rid him quite:
let him deliver him, because
in him he doth delight.
But thou art hee that me out of
the belly forth didst take:
when I was on my mothers breasts,
to hope thou didst mee make.
Vnto thee from the tender-womb
committed been have I:
yea thou hast been my mighty-God
from my mothers belly.
Be thou not farre away from mee,
for tribulation
exceeding great is neere at hand,
for helper there is none.
Mee many buls on every side
about have compassed:
the mighty-buls of Bashan have
mee round invironed.
They have with their wide-opened-mouths
so gaped mee upon;
like as it were a ravening
and a roaring Lion.
As water I am poured-out,
and all my bones sundred:
my heart in midst of my bowels,
is like to wax melted.
My strength like a potsherd is dryde;
and my tongue fast-cleaveth
unto my jawes, & thou hast brought
me to the dust of death.
For dogs have compast me about;
th' assembly me beset
of the wicked; they pierced through
my hands, also my feet.
My bones I may them number all:
they lookt, they did me view.
My cloths among them they did part:
and lot for my coat threw.
But thou Lord be not far, my strength,
to help me hasten thou.
My soule from sword, my darling from
the powre of dogs rescue.
And from the mouth of the Lion
give me salvation free:
for thou from hornes of Vnicornes
answer hast given mee.
Thy name, I will declare to them
that Brethren are to mee:
in midst of congregation
I will give prayse to thee.
Yee that doe feare the Lord prayse him;
all Iacobs seed prayse yee,
him glorify, & dread him all
yee Israels seed that bee.
For he the poors affliction
loaths not, nor doth despise;
nor hides his face from him, but hears
when unto him hee cryes.
Concerning thee shall be my prayse
in the great assembly:
before them that him reverence
performe my vowes will I.
The meek shall eat & be suffic'd:
Iehovah prayse shall they
that doe him seek: your heart shall live
unto perpetuall aye.
All ends of th'earth remember shall
and turne unto the Lord:
and thee all heathen-families
to worship shall accord.
Because unto Iehovah doth
the kingdome appertaine:
and he among the nations
is ruler Soveraigne.
Earths-fat-ones, eat & worship shall:
all who to dust descend,
(though none can make alive his soule)
before his face shall bend.
With service a posterity
him shall attend upon;
to God it shall accounted bee
a generation.
Come shall they, & his righteousnes
by them declar'd shall bee,
unto a people yet unborne,
that done this thing hath hee.

DIV2.HEAD: 23 A Psalme of David.
DIV2.L: THe Lord to mee a shepheard is,
Hee in the folds of tender-grasse,
doth cause mee downe to lie:
To waters calme me gently leads
he doth in paths of righteousnes:
for his names sake leade mee.
Yea though in valley of deaths shad
I walk, none ill I'le feare:
because thou art with mee, thy rod,
For mee a table thou hast spread,
thou dst annoynt my head with oyle,
and in the Lords house I shall dwell
so long as dyes shall bee.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 24 A psalme of david.
DIV2.L: and i his plce of holnes,
who is it that shall stand?
who hath not lifted up his soule,
of them that seek thy face:
of them that doe inquire for him:
e yee lift up: & there into
of wrlike rmies, hee the King

LG.L: I Lift my soule to thee o Lord.
My God I trust in thee,
let mee not be asham'd: nor let
my foes joy over mee.
Yea, all that wait on thee shall not,
be fill'd with shamefulnes:
but they shall be ashamed all,
who without cause transgresse.
Thy wayes, Iehovah, make mee know,
thy paths make me discerne.
Cause mee my steps to order well,
in thy truth, & mee learne,
For thou God of my saving health,
on thee I wait all day.
Thy bowels, Lord, & thy mercyes
minde; for they are for aye.
Sinnes of my youth remember not,
neither my trespasses:
after thy mercy minde thou mee
o Lord for thy goodnes.
Good and upright God is, therefore
will sinners teach the way.
The meek he'l guide in judgemen: &
will teach the meek his way.
Ihovahs paths they mercy are,
ll of hem ruth also,
to hem tht keep his covenant,
and testimoies do.
Fr ty nam sake o Iehovah,
freely doe thou
mine owne perverse iniquitie:
because that great is it.
Who fears the Lord, him hee will teach
the way that he shall chuse.
his soule shall dwell at ease, his seed
as heirs the earth shall vse.
The secret of God is with those
that doe him reverence:
and of his covenant he them
will give intelligence.
Mine eyes continually are
upon Iehovah set:
for it is hee that will bring forth
my feet out of the net.
Vnto me-wards turne thou thy face,
and on mee mercy show:
because I solitary am
afflicted poore also.
My hearts troubles inlarged are;
from my distresse me bring.
See mine affliction, & my paine;
and pardon all my sin.
Mark my foes; for they many are,
and cruelly mee hate,
My soule keep, free mee; nor let mee
be sham'd, who on thee wait.
Let soundnes, & uprightnesse keep
mee: for I trust in the.
Israel from his troubles all,
o God, doe thou set fre.

DIV2.HEAD: 26 A .
DIV2.L: IVdge mee, o Lord, for I have walkt
and I have trusted in the Lord,
For thy grace is before mine eyes;
and in thy truth walk I▪
I sat not with vaine men, nor goe
In cleannesse, Lord, I'le wash mine hands,
That I may preach with thankfull-voyce,
My soule with sinners gather not,
with men of blood my life.
In whose hand 's guile, in whose right hand
My foot stands right: in th'assembly

LG.L: THe Lord my light, & my health is,
what shall make me dismaid?
The Lord is my lifes-strength, of whom
should I then be afrayd?
When wicked men, mine enemies,
and my foes in battel;
against mee come, to eate my flesh,
themselves stumbled & fell.
If that an hosta against mee camp,
my heart undaunted is:
if war against mee should arise,
I am secure in this.
One thing of God I asked have,
which I will still request:
that I may in the house of God,
all dayes of my life rest:
To see the beauty of the Lord,
and in his Temple seeke.
For in his tent in th'evill-day,
hidden hee will mee keepe:
Hee will me hide in secrecy
of his pavillion:
and will me highly lift upon
the rocks-munition.
Moreover at this-time my head
lifted on high shall bee,
above mine enemies, who doe
about encompasse mee.
Therefore in's tent I'le sacrifice,
of joye an offering,
into Iehovah, sing will I,
yea, I will prayses sing.
When as I with my voyce doe cry,
mee, o Iehovah, heare▪
have mercy also upon mee,
and unto mee answer.
When thou didst say, seek yee my face,
my heart sayd unto thee,
thy countenance, o Iehovah,
it shall be sought by mee.
Hide not thy face from mee, nor off
in wrath thy servant cast:
God of my health, leave, leave not mee,
my helper been thou hast.
My father & my mother both
though they doe mee forsake,
yet will Iehovah gathering
unto himselfe me take.
Iehovah, teach thou mee the way,
and be a guide to mee
in righteous path, because of them
that mine observers bee.
Give mee not up unto the will
of my streight-enemies:
for witnesse false against me stand,
and breath out cruelties.
I should haue fainted, had not I
believed for to see,
Iehovahs goodnes in the land
of them that living bee.
Doe thou upon Iehovah wait▪
bee stablished, & let
thine heart be strengthened, & thine hope
upon Iehovah set.
IEHOVAH, unto thee I cry,
my Rock, be thou not deafe me fro:
lest thou be dumb from mee & I
be like them downe to pit that go.
Heare thou the voyce of my request
for grace, when unto thee I cry:
when I lift up mine hands unto
thine Oracle of Sanctity.
With ill men draw me not way,
with workers of unrighteousnes,
that with their neighbours peace doe speak,
but in their hands is wickednes.
Give thou to them like to their works
and like the evill of their deeds:
give them like to their handy-works,
and render unto them their meeds.
Because unto Iehovahs work
they did not wise-attention yeild,
neither unto his handy work,
them he will wast, but not up-build.
The Lord be blest, for he hath heard
the voyce of my requests for grace.
God is my strength, my shield, in him
my heart did trust, & helpt I was:
Therefore my heart will gladnes shew,
and with my song I'le him confesse▪
The Lord of his annoynted ones
their strength, & towre of safety is.
Salvation to thy people give,
and blesse thou thine inheritance,
and ev'n unto eternity
doe thou them feed & them advance.

LG.HEAD: This. After the common tunes.
LG.L: Save Lord, thy people, & doe thou
blesse thine inheritance:
and unto all eternity
them feed & them advance.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 29 A psalme of David.
DIV2.L: VNto the Lord doe yee ascribe
unto the Lord doe yee ascribe
Vnto the Lord doe yee ascribe
Gods voyce breaks Cedars: yea God breaks
He makes them like a calfe to skip:
and like to a young Vnicorne
Gods voyce divides the flames of fire.
the desart shake: the Lord doth cause
The Lords voyce makes the hindes to calve,
and in his temple every one
The Lord sate on the flouds: the Lord
God to his folk gives strength: the Lord

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 30 A Psalme & Song, at the dedication of the house of David.
DIV2.L: for thou hast lift up mee;
and over mee thou hast not made
O Lord my God, to thee I cry'de
and thou hast made mee whole.
Out of the grave, o Iehovah,
thou hast brought up my soue:
Thou mad'st mee live, I went not downe
to pit. Sing to the Lord,
(yee his Saints) & give thanks when yee
For but a moment in his wrath;
life in his love doth stay:
weeping may lodge with us a night
but joye at break of day.
Lord by thy favour thou hast made
Thou hidst thy face, I troubled was.
o Lord: also my humble suit
What gaine is in my blood; when I
shall dust give glory unto thee?
shall it thy truth make knowne?
Doe thou mee o Iehovah, heare,
Iehovah, o bee thou to mee
Thou into dancing for my sake
That sing to thee my glory may,
o Lord my God, I will give thanks

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 31 To the chief Musician, a psalme of David.

LG.L: IN thee, o Lord, I put my trust,
let me be shamed never:
according to thy righteousnes
o doe thou mee deliver.
Bow downe to mee thine eare, with speed
let mee deliverance have:
be thou my strong rock, for an house
of defence mee to save.
Because thou unto mee a rock
and my fortresse wilt bee:
therefore for thy names sake doe thou,
leade mee & guide thou mee.
Doe thou mee pull out of the net,
which they have for mee layd
so privily: because that thou
art to mee a sure ayd.
Into thy hands my spirit I
reposing doe commit:
Iehovah God of verity,
thou hast redeemed it.
I hated them that have regard
to lying vanity:
but I in God trust. I'le be glad,
and joy in thy mercy:
Because thou hast considered
my afflicting distresse;
thou hast my soule acknowledged
in painfull anguishes;
And thou hast not inclosed mee
within the enemies hand:
thou mad'st my feet within the place
of liberty to stand.
Have mercy upon mee, o Lord,
for in distresse am I,
with grief mine eye consumed is,
my soule & my belly.
For my life with grief & my years
with sighs are consumed:
because of my sin, my strength failes,
and my bones are wasted.
To all my foes I was a scorne,
chiefly my neighbours to;
a feare to freinds: they that saw mee
without, did flye me fro.
I am forgot as a dead man
that's out of memory:
and like a vessel that is broke
ev'n such a one am I.
Because that I of many men
the slandering did heare,
round about me on every side
there was exceeding feare:
While as that they did against mee
counsell together take,
they craftily have purposed
my life away to make.
But o Iehovah, I in thee
my confidence have put
I sayd thou art my God. My times
within thy hand are shut:
From the hands of mine enemies
doe thou deliver mee,
and from the men who mee against
my persecuters bee.
Thy countenance for to shine forth
upon thy servant make:
o give to me salvation
even for thy mercy sake.
Let me not be asham'd, o Lord,
for cal'd on thee I have:
let wicked men be sham'd, let them
be silent in the grave.
Let lying lips be silenced,
that against men upright
doe speak such things as greivous are;
in pride, & in despight.
How great 's thy goodnes, thou for thē
that feare thee hast hidden:
which thou work'st for them that thee trust,
before the Sonnes of men.
Thou in the secret of thy face,
shalt hide them from mans pride:
in a pavillion, from the strife
of tongues, thou wilt them hide.
O let Iehovah blessed be;
for he hath shewed mee
his loving kindnes wonderfull
in a fenced-cittie.
For I in hast sayd, I am cast
from the sight of thine eyes:
yet thou hearst the voyce of my fuit,
when to thee were my cryes.
O love the Lord all ye his Saints;
because the Lord doth guard
the faithfull, but the proud doer
doth plenteously reward.
See that yee be encouraged,
and let your heart wax strong:
all whosoever hopefully
doe for Iehovah long.

DIV2.HEAD: 32 A psalme of David, Maschil,
DIV2.L: O Blessed is the man who hath
O blessed is the man to whom
and he who such a spirit hath
When I kept silence then my bones,
with age; by meanes of my roaring
For day & night thy hand on mee,
into the drought of Summer time
Against my selfe my sin, sayd I,
For this each godly one to thee
surely in floods of waters great,
come nigh him shall not they.
Thou art my hyding-place, thou shalt
I will instruct thee, also teach
thee in the way will I
which thou shalt goe, I will to thee
Like to the horse & mule, which have
whose mouths are held with bridle-bit,
that come not neere to thee.
To those men that ungodly are,
but him that trusteth in the Lord,
and all that are upright heart

LG.L: YEe just in God rejoyce,
pryse well th'upright doth sure:
Prayse God with Harp, with psaltry
to him, on ten string 'd lute.
Sing to him a new song,
aloud play skilfully.
For the Lords word is right: and all
his works in verity.
He loveth righteousnes,
and also equity:
the earth replenished is with
the Lords benignity.
By the word of the Lord
the heavens had their frame,
and by the spirit of his mouth,
all the host of the same.
The waters of the seas,
he gathers as an heape;
together as in store-houses
he layeth up the deepe.
Be all the earth in feare,
because of Iehovah:
let all the dwellers of the world
before him stand in awe.
Because he did but speak
the word, & it was made:
he gave out the commandement,
and it was firmly stay'd.
The Lord to nought doth bring
the nations counsell; hee
devises of the people makes
of none effect to bee.
The counsell of the Lord
abide for ever shall,
the of his heart
to generations all.
O blessed nation,
whose God Iehovah is:
and people whom for heritage
chosen hee hath for his.
The Lord from heaven looks,
all Sonnes of men views well.
From his firme dwelling hee looks forth,
on all that on earth dwell.
The hearts of all of them
alike he fashioneth:
and all their operations
he well considereth.
By multitude of boast
there is no King saved▪
nor is by multitude of strength
the strong delivered.
A horse a vaine thing is
to be a saviour:
nor shall he work deliverance
by greatnes of his power.
On them that doe him feare
loe, is Iehovahs eye:
upon them that doe place their hope
on his benignity.
To save alive in dearth,
d their soule from death ree.
Our soule doth for Iehovah way,
our help, & shield is hee.
For our heart joyes in him:
for in's pure name trust wee.
Let thy mercy (Lord) be on us:
like as we trust in thee.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 34 A psalme of David, whē he changed his behaviour before Abimelech, who drove him away & he departed.

LG.L: ILe blesse God alwayes, his prayse shall
still in my mouth be had.
My soule shall boast in God: the meeke
shall heare this & bee glad.
Exalt the Lord with mee, his name
let us together advance.
I sought, God heard, who gave from all
my fears deliverance.
Him they beheld, & light'ned were,
nor sham'd were their faces.
This poore man cry'd, the Lord him heard,
and freed from all distresse.
His camp about them round doth pith
the Angell of the Lord;
who doe him feare; and to them doth
deliverance afford.
O ast, also consider yee,
that God is good: o blest,
that man is ever whose hope doth
for safety in him rest.
O stand in feare of Iehovah,
his holy ones who bee.
because that such as doe him feare
not any want shall see.
The Lions young doe suffer lack,
and suffer hungering:
but they that seek Iehovah, shall
not want any good thing.
I will you teach to feare the Lord:
come children hark to mee.
Who is the man that willeth life:
and loves good dayes to see?
Thy tongue from evill, & thy lips
from speaking guile keep thou.
Depart from evill & doe good:
seek peace, and it follow.
Vpon the men that righteous are
the Lord doth set his eye:
and likewise he doth bow his eare
when unto him they cry.
Iehovahs face is set against
them that doe wickedly:
that he of them from off the earth
may cut the memory.
They cry'd, God heard, & set them free,
from their distresses all.
To broken hearts the Lord is neere,
and contrite save he shall.
The just mans sorrows many are,
from all God sets him free.
Hee kepeth all his bones, that none
of them shall broken bee.
Evill shall certainly bring death
the wicked man upon:
and those that hate the just shall come
to desolation.
The soules of them that doe him serve,
Iehovah doth redeeme:
nor ny shall be desolate,
that put their trust in him.
PLead, ord, with them that with me plead:
fight against them that fight with mee.
Of shield & buckler take thou hold,
stand up my helper for to bee.
Draw out the speare & stop the way
'gainst them that my pursuers bee:
and doe thou say unto my soule
I am salvation unto thee.
Let them confounded be, & sham'd,
that seek my soule how they may spill:
lt them be turned back & sham'd
that in their thoughts devise mine ill.
As chaffe before the winde, let them
be, & Gods Angell them driving.
Let their way dark & slippery bee,
and the Lords Angell them chasing.
For in a pit without a cause,
they hidden have for me a net:
which they without a cause have digg'd
that they there in my soule may get.
Let unknowne ruin come on him,
and let his net that he doth hide,
himselfe insnare: let him into
the very same destruction slyde.
My soule shall in the Lord be glad:
in his slvation joyfull bee
And all my bones shall also say,
o Lord, who is like unto thee?
Who from the stronger then himselfe
the poore afflicted settest free:
the poore afflicted & needy,
from such as spoylers of him bee.
False witnesses did up arise:
what I knew not they charg'd on mee.
Evill for good they mee repay'd,
whereby my soule might spoyled bee,
But I, when they were sick, was cloath'd
with sackcloath, & I afflicted
my soule with fasting, & my pray'r
into my bosom returned.
I walked as if he had been
my neere freind or mine owne brother:
I heavily bow'd downe as one
that mourneth for his owne mother.
But they in mine adversity
rejoyced, & they gathered
themselves together: yea abjects
themselves against mee gathered;
And I was ignorant hereof;
and they unceasantly mee teare,
With hypocrites, mockers in feasts;
at me their teeth they gnashing were.
How long o Lord wilt thou look on?
my soule from their destructions,
o doe thou set at liberty,
my only one from the Lions.
I freely will give thanks to thee
within the congregation great:
and I thy prayses will set forth
where there be many people met.
Those that are wrongfully my foes,
let them not rejoyce over mee:
neither let them wink with the eye,
that are my haters causlesly.
Because that they doe not speak pece▪
but in their thoughts they doe invent
deceitfull matters against them
that in the land for peace are bent.
Gainst me they op'ned their mouths wid
& sayd, ah, ah our eye it saw.
Thou saw'st it (Lord) hold not thy peace:
Lord, from me be not far away.
Stirre up & wake to my judgement,
my God & my Lord, to my plea.
After thy justice, judge me, Lord
my God, lest or'e me joy should they.
Let them not say within their hearts,
aha, our soules desire have wee:
we now have swallowed him up,
o let them never say of mee.
Sham'd let them be & confounded
joyntly, who at my hurt are glad:
let them that 'gainst me magnify,
with shame & dishonour be clad.
Let them for joy shout, & be glad
that favour doe my righteous ause:
yea, let them say continually,
extolled be the Lord with prayse,
Who doth in the prosperity
of his servants his pleasure stay
And my tongue of thy justice shall,
and of thy prayse speake all the day.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 36. To the chief Musician a psalme of David, the servant of the Lord.

LG.L: THe trespasse of the wicked one
saith in assured-wise:
within my heart, the feare of God
is not before his eyes.
For in his eyes he sooths himselfe:
his sin is found meane while
hatefull. The words of his mouth are
iniquity & guile:
He to be wise, to doe good leaves.
He mischief plotts on's bed,
he sets himselfe in way not good:
he hath not ill hated.
Thy mercy (Lord) in heaven is,
to clouds thy faithfullnes.
Thy judgements a great deep, like great
mountains thy righteousnes:
Thou savest mn & beast, o Lord.
Ho pretious is thy grace,
therfore i shadow of thy wings
mens sonnes their trust doe place.
They of the faes of thy-house
unto the full shall take:
and of the river of thy joyes
to drink thou shalt them make.
For with thee is the spring of life:
in thy light wee'll see light.
To them that know thee stretch thy grace;
to right in heart thy right.
Let no proud foot against me come,
nor wicked hand move mee.
Wrong doers there are fal'n cast downe,
and rays'd they cannot bee,
FRet not thy selfe because of those
that evill workers bee,
nor envious bee against the men
that work iniquitie.
For like unto the grasse they shall
be cut downe, suddenly:
and like unto the tender herb
they withering shall dye.
Vpon the Lord put thou thy trust,
and bee thou doing good,
so shalt thou dwell within the land,
and sure thou shalt have food.
Se hat thou set thy hearts delight
also upon the Lord,
and the desyers of thy heart
to thee he will afford.
Trust in the Lord: & hee'l it work,
to him commit thy wy.
As light thy justice hee'l bring forth,
thy judgement as noone day.
Rest in Iehovah, & for him
with patience doe thou stay:
fret not thy selfe because of him
who prospers in his way,
Nor at the man, who brings to passe
the crafts he doth devise.
Cease ire, & wrath leave: to doe ill
thy selfe fret in no wife.
For evil doers shall be made
by cutting downe to fall:
but those that wayt upon the Lord,
the land inherit shall.
For yet a litle while, & then
the wicked shall not bee:
yea, thou shalt diligently mark
his place, & it not see.
But meek ones the inheritance
shall of the earth possesse:
also they shall themselves delight
in multitude of peace.
The wicked plotts against the just,
gnashing at him his teeth.
The Lord shall laugh at him: because
his day coming he seeth.
The wicked have drawne out their sword,
& bent their bowe have they,
to cast the poor & needy downe,
to kill th'upright in way.
Their sword shall enter their owne heart
their bowes shall broken bee.
The just mans little, better is
then wices treasurie.
For th'armes of wicked shall be broke:
the Lord the just oth stay.
The Lord doth know upright mens dayes:
and their lot is for aye.
Neither shall they ashamed bee
in any time of ill:
and when the dayes of famine come,
they then shall have their fill.
But wicked, & foes of the Lord
as lambs fat shall decay:
they shall consume: yea into smoake
they shall consume away.
The man ungodly borroweth,
but he doth not repay:
but he that righteous is doth shew
mercy, & gives away.
For such as of him blessed bee,
the earth inherit shall,
and they that of him cursed are,
by cutting downe shall fall.
The foot-steps of a godly man
they are by Iehovah
established: & also hee
delighteth in his way.
Although he fall, yet shall he not
be utterly downe cast:
beuse Iehovah with his hand
doth underprop him fast.
I have been young & now am old;
yet have I never seen
the just man left, nor that his seed
for bread have beggars been.
But every day hee's mercifull,
and lends: his seed is blest.
Depart from evill, & doe good:
and ever dwell at rest.
Because the Lord doth judgement love,
his Saints forsakes not hee;
kept ever are they: but cut off
the sinners seed shall bee.
The just inherit shall the land,
and therein ever dwell.
The just mans mouth wisdome doth speak▪
his tongue doth judgement .
The law of his God is in's heart:
none of his steps slideth.
The wicked watcheth for the just,
and him to slay seeketh.
Iehovah will not such a one
relinquish in his hand,
neither will he condemne him when
adjudged he doth stand.
Wayt on the Lord, & keep his way,
and hee shll hee exalt
th'earth to inheri: when cut off
the wicked see thou shalt.
The wicked men I have beheld
in mighty pow'r to bee:
also himsefe spreading abroad
like to a green-bay-tree.
Neverthelesse he past away,
and loe, then was not hee;
moreover I did seek for him,
but found hee could not bee.
Take notice of the perfect man,
and the upright attend:
because that unto such a man
peace is his latter end.
But such men that transgressors are
together perish shall:
the latter end shall be cut off
of the ungodly all,
But the salvation of the just
doth of Iehovah come:
he is their strength to them in times
that are most troublesome.
Yea, help & free them will the Lord:
he shall deliver them
from wiced men, because that they
doe put their trust in him.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 38 A psalme of David, to bring to remembrance.

LG.L: LORD, in thy wrath rebuke me not:
nor in thy hot rage chasten mee.
Because thine hand doth presse me sore:
and in me thy shafts fastened bee.
There is no sounnes in my flesh,
because thine anger I am in:
nor is there any rest within
my bones, by reason of my sin.
Because that mine iniquityes
ascended are above my head:
like as an heavy burden, they
to heavy upon me are layd.
My wounds stink, and corrupt they be:
my foolishnes doth make it so.
I troubled am, & much bow'd downe;
all the day long I mourning goe.
For with foule sores my loynes are fill'd:
& in my flesh is no soundnes.
I'me weak & broken sore; I roar'd
because of my hearts restlessnes.
All my desire's before thee, Lord;
nor is my groaning hid from thee.
My heart doth pant, my strength me fails:
& mine eye sight is gone from mee.
My freinds & lovers from my sore
stand off: off stand my kinsmen eke.
And they lay snares that seek my life,
that seek my hurt, they mischief speak,
And all day long imagin guile,
But as one deafe, I did not heare,
and as a dumb man I became
as if his mouth not open were.
Thus was I as man that heares not,
& in whose mouth reproofes none were.
Because o Lod, in thee I hope:
o Lord my God, thou wilt mee hea
For sayd I, or'e me thy oy:
when my foot , they vant the more
themselves 'gaint me. For I o halt
am neere, my grief's still mee before.
For my transgression I'le declare;
I for my sins will sorry bee.
But yet my lively foes are strong,
who falsly hate me, multiplie.
Moreover they that doe repay
evill in stead of good to mee,
because I follow what is good,
to mee they adversaryes bee.
Iehovah, doe not mee forsake:
my God o doe not farre depart
from mee. Make hast unto mine ayd,
o Lord who my salvation art.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 39 To the chief musician, even to Ieduthun, a Psalme of David.

LG.L: I Sayd, I will look to my wayes,
lest I sin with my tongue:
I'le keep my mouth with bit, while I
the wicked am among.
With silence tyed was my tongue,
my mouth I did refraine,
From speaking that thing which is good,
and stirred was my paine.
Mine heart within me waxed hot,
while I was musing long,
inkindled in me was the fire;
then spake I with my tongue.
Mine end, o Lord, & of my dayes
let mee the measure learne;
that what a momentany thing
I am I may discerne.
Behold thou mad'st my dayes a span,
mine age as nought to thee:
surely each man at's best estate,
is wholly vanity. Selah.
Sure in a vaine show walketh man;
sure stir'd in vaine they are:
he heaps up riches, & knows not
who shall the same gather.
And now, o Lord what wayt I for?
my hope is upon thee.
Free me from all my trespasses:
the fooles scorne make not mee.
I was dumb nor opned my mouth,
this done because thou hast.
Remove thy stroke away from mee:
by thy hands blow I wast.
When with rebukes thou dost correct
man for iniquity;
thou blast's his beauty like a moth:
sure each man 's vanity. Selah.
Heare my pray'r, Lord, hark to my cry,
be not still at my tears:
for stranger, & pilgrim with thee,
I 'me, as all my fathers.
O turne aside a while from mee,
that I may strength recall:
before I doe depart fom hence,
and be noe more at all.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 40. To the chief musician, a psalme▪ of David.

LG.L: WIth expectation for the Lord
I wayted patiently,
and hee inclined unto mee.
also he heard my cry.
He brought mee out of dreadfull-pit,
out of the miery clay:
and set my feet upon a rock,
hee stablished my way.
And in my mouth put a new song,
of prayse our God unto:
many shall see, & feare, upon
the Lord shall trust also.
Blest is the man that on the Lord
maketh his trust abide:
nor doth the proud respect, nor such
to lies as turne aside.
O thou Iehovah, thou my God,
hast many a wonder wrought:
and likewise towards us thou hast
eived many a thought.
Their summe cannot be reck'ned up,
in order unto thee:
would I declare & speak of them,
beyond account they bee.
Thou sacrifice & offering
wouldst not; thou boar'st mine eare:
burnt offring, & sin offering
thou neither didst requere.
Then sayd I: loe, I come: ith books
rolle it is writt of mee.
To doe thy will, God, I delight▪
thy laws in my beart bee.
In the great congregation
thy righteousnes I show:
loe, I have not refraynd my lips,
Iehovah, thou dost know.
I have not hid thy righteousnes
within my heart alone:
I have declar'd thy faithfullnes
and thy salvation:
Thy mercy nor thy truth have I
from the great Church conceald.
Let not thy tender mercyes bee
from mee o Lord with-held.
Let both thy kindnes & thy truth
keep me my life throughout.
Because innumerable ills
have compast mee about:
My sins have caught me so that I
not able am to see:
more are they then hairs of my head,
therefore my heart fails mee
Be pleas'd Lord, to deliver mee
to help me Lord make hast.
At once abasht & sham'd let bee
who seek my soule to waste:
Let them be driven back, & sham'd,
that wish me misery.
Let them be waste, to quit their shame,
that say to me, fy fy.
Let all be glad, & joy in thee,
that seek thee: let them say
who thy salvation love, the Lord
be magnifyde alway.
I both distrest & needy am,
the Lord yet thinks on mee:
my help & my deliverer thou
my God, doe not tarry.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 41 To the chief musician, a psalme of David.

LG.L: BLessed is hee that wisely doth
unto the poore attend:
the Lord will him deliverance
in time of trouble send.
Him God will keep, & make to live,
on earth hee blest shall be,
nor doe thou him unto the will
give of his enemie.
Vpon the bed of languishing,
the Lord will strengthen him:
thou also wilt make all his bed
within his sicknes time.
I sayd, Iehouah, o be thou
mercifull unto mee;
heale thou my soule, because that I
have sinned against thee.
Those men that be mine enemies,
with evill mee defame:
when will the time come hee shall dye,
and perish shall his name?
And if he come to see mee, hee
speaks vanity: his heart
sin to it selfe heaps, when hee goes
forth hee doth it impart.
All that me hate, against mee they
together whisper still:
against me they imagin doe
to mee malicious ill.
Thus doe they say some ill disease,
unto him cleaveth sore:
and seing now he lyeth downe,
he shall rise up noe more.
Moreover my familiar freind,
on whom my trust I set,
his heele against mee lifted up,
who of my bread did eat.
But Lord me pitty, & mee rayse,
that I may them requite.
By this I know assuredly,
in mee thou dost delight:
For o're mee triumphs not my foe,
And mee, thou dost mee stay,
in mine integrity; & set'st
mee thee before for aye.
Blest hath Iehovah Israels God
from everlasting been,
also unto everlasting:
Amen, yea and Amen.

DIV2.HEAD: PSALME 42 To the chief musician, Maschil, for the Sonnes of Korh.

LG.L: LIke as the Hart panting doth bray
after the water brooks,
even in such wise o God, my soule,
after thee panting looks.
For God, even for the liuing God,
my soule it thirsteth sore:
oh when shall I come & appeare,
the face of God before.
My teares have been unto mee meat,
by night also by day,
while all the day they unto mee
where is thy God doe say.
When as I doe in minde record
these things, then me upon
I doe my soule out poure, for I
wit multitude had gone:
With them unto Gods house I went
with voyce of joy & prayse:
I with a multitud did goe
that did keepe-holy-days.
My soule why art cast downe? & at
stirr'd in mee: thy hope place
in God, for yet him prayse I shall
for the help of his face.
My God, my soule in mee's cast downe,
therefore thee minde I will
from Iordanes & Hemonites land,
and from the litle hill.
At the noyse of thy water spouts
deep unto deep doth call:
thy waves they are gone over mee,
also thy billowes all.
His loving kindnes yet the Lord
command will in the day:
a nd in the night his song with mee,
to my lifes God I'le pray.
I unto God will say, my Rock
why hast thou forgot mee?
why goe I sad, by reason of
pressure of th' enemie.
As with a sword within my bones
my foes reproach mee do:
while all the day, where is thy God?
they doe say mee unto.
My soule o wherefore dost thou bowe
thy selfe downe heavily;
and wherefore in mee makest thou
a stirr tumultuously?
Hope thou in God, because I shall
with prayse him yet advance:
who is my God, also he is
health of my countenance.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 43.
DIV2.L: IVdge me, o God, & plead my cause
For of my strength thou art the God,
why cast's thou mee thee fro:
why goe I mourning for the sore
Thy light o send out & thy truth,
Then will I to Gods Altar goe,
upon the Harp o God my God
My soule o wherfore dost thou howe
and wherefore in mee makest thou
Hope thou in God, because I shall
who is my God, also he is

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 44 To the chief musician, for the sonnes of Korah.

LG.L: WEE with our eares have hard, o God,
our fathers have us told,
what works thou diddest in their dayes,
in former dayes of old.
How thy hand drave the heathen out,
and them thou planted hast;
how thou the people didst afflict,
and hou didst them out-cast.
For they got not by their owne sword
the lands possession,
neither yet was it their owne arme
wrought their salvation:
But thy right hand, thine arme also,
thy countenances light;
because that of thine owne good will
thou didst in them delight.
Thou art my king, o mighty God,
dost the same indure:
doe thou for Iacob by command
deliverances procure.
Through thee as with a horne wee will
push downe our enemies:
through thy name will wee tread them downe
that up against us rise.
Because that I will in no wise
any affiance have,
upon my bow, neither is it
my sword that shall mee save.
But from our enemies us thou sav'd,
and put our foes to shame.
I God wee boast all the day long,
and for aye prayse thy name. Selah.
But thou hast cast us off away,
thou makest us also
to be asham'd; neither dost thou
forth with our armies goe.
Vs from before the eemy
thou makest back recoyle:
likewise they which our haters bee,
for themselves us doe spoyle.
Thou hast us given like to sheep
to slaughter that belong:
also thou hast us scattered
the heathen folk among.
Thou dost thy people se to sale
whereby no wealth doth rise:
neither dost thou obtaine increase
of riches by their price.
Vnto our neighbours a reproach
thou doest us expose,
a scorne we are & mocking stock,
to them that us inclose.
Among the heathen people thou
a by word dost us make:
also among the nations,
at us their heads they shake.
Before me my confusion
it is continually,
and of my countenance the shame
hath over covered mee.
Because of his voyce that doth scorne,
and scoffingly despight:
by reason of the enemy,
and selfe revenging wight.
All this is come on us, wee yet
have not forgotten thee:
neither against thy covenant
have wee dealt faithleslie.
Our heart is not turn'd back, nor have
our steps from thy way stray'd;
Though us thou brake in dragons place,
and hid us in deaths shade.
had wee forgot Gods name, or stretcht
to a strange God our hands:
Shall not God search this out? for hee
hearts secrets understands.
Yea, for thee all day wee are kil'd:
counted as sheep to slay.
Awake, why sleepst thou, Lord? arise,
cast us not off for aye.
Thy countenance away from us
o wherefore dost thou hide?
of our grief & oppression
forgetfull dost abide.
For our soule is bowd downe to dust:
to earth cleaves our belly.
Rise for our help, & us redeeme,
because of thy mercy.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 45 To the chief musician upon Shoshannim, for∣the sonnes of Korah, Maschil a song of loves.

LG.L: MY heart good mater boyleth forth,
my works touching th King
I speak: my tongue is as the pen
of Scribe swiftly writing.
Fairer thou art then sonnes of men,
grace in thy lips is shed:
because of this the Lord hath thee
for evermore blessed.
Thy wasting sword o mighty on
gird thou upon thy thigh:
thy glorious-magnificnce,
and comely majesty.
Ride forth upon the word of truth,
meeknes & righteousnes:
and thy right hand shall lead thee forth
in works of dreadfulnes.
Within the heart of the kings foes
thine arrows piercing bee:
whereby the people overcome,
shall fall downe under thee.
Thy throne o God, for ever is,
the scepter of thy state
right scepter is. Iustice thou lov'st,
but wickednes dost hate:
Because of this, God ev'n thy God
hee hath annoynted thee,
with oyle of ladnes above them,
that thy companions bee.
Myrths, Alos, and Cassias smell,
all of thy garments had:
out of the yvory pallacs
wherby they made thee glad.
Amongst thine honourable maids
kings daughters present were,
the Queen is set at thy right hand
in fine gold of Ophir.
Harken o daughter, & behold,
doe thou incline thine eare:
doe thou forget thine owne people,
and house of thy father.
So shall the king delighting-rest
himselfe in thy beautie:
and bowing downe worship thou him,
because thy Lord is hee.
Then shall be present with a gift
the daughter there of Tyre:
the wealthy ones of the people
thy favour shall desire.
The daughter of the king she is
all glorious within:
and with imbroderies of gold,
her garments wrought have been.
She is led in unto the king
in robes with needle wrought:
the virgins that doe follow her
shall unto thee be brought.
They shall be brought forth with gladnes,
also with rejoycing,
so shall they entrance have into
the Pallace of the king.
Thy children shall in stead of those
that were thy fathers bee:
whom thou mayst place in all the earth
in princely diginty.
Thy name remembred I will make
through generations all:
therefore for ever & for aye
the people prayse thee shall.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 46 To the chief musician, for the sonnes of-Korah, a song upon Alemoth.
DIV2.L: GOD is our refuge, strength, & help
Therefore we will not be afrayd,
Though mountaines move to midst of seas
and troubled be, at whose swellings
There is a river streames whereof
the holy place the tent wherin
God is within the midst of her,
God shall be unto her an help,
he did give forth his thundering voyce
the earth did melt with feare.
The God of Armies is with us
the God of Iacob is for us
O come yee forth behold the works
which on the earth he brough.
Vnto the utmost ends of th'earth
the speare he cuts, the bowe he breaks,
Be still, & know that I am God,
among the heathen: through the earth
The God of armyes is with us,
the God of Iacob is for us

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 47. To the chief musician: a psalme for the Sonnes of Korah.
DIV2.L: CLap hands all people, shout for joy,
to God with voyce of singing mirth:
a great King over all the earth.
People to us he doth subdue,
and nations under our feet lay.
For us our heritage he chose,
God is ascended with a shout:
Sing psalme to God, sing psalmes, sing-psalmes
unto our King with singing voyce.
For God is King of all the earth,
Over the heathen God will reigne
for shields of th'earth to God belong:

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 48 To the chief musician, a song & psalme for the sonnes of Korah.

LG.L: GReat is Iehovah, & he is
to be praysed greatly
within the city of our God,
in his mountaine holy.
For situation beautifull,
the joy of the whole earth
mount Sion; the great Kings city
on the sides of the north.
God in her pallaces is known
to be a refuge high.
For loe, the kings assembled were:
they past together by.
They saw, & so they merveiled,
were troubled, fled for feare.
Trembling seiz'd on them there & paine
like her that childe doth beare.
The naies that of Tarshish ar
in piees thou breakest:
ev'n with a very blast of winde
coming out of the east.
As we heard, so we saw within
the Lord of hoasts citty,
in our Gods citty, God will it
stablish eternally. Selah.
O God we have had thoughts upon
thy free benignity,
wirhin the very midle part
of thy temple holy,
According to thy name, o God
so is thy prayse unto
the ends of earth: thy right hand 's full
of righteousnes lso.
Let the mountaine Sion rejoyce,
and triumph let them make
who are the daughters of Iudah,
ev'n for thy udgements sake.
About th hill of Son walk,
and goe about he yee,
