Ty words most sure: Lord, holines

LG.L: O LORD God, unto whom there doe
revenges appertaine:
o God, to whom vengeance belongs,
clearly shine forth againe.
Exalt thy selfe, o thou that art
Iudge of the earth throughout:
render a recompence unto
all those that are so stout.
Iehovah, o how long shall they
tht doe walk wickedly?
how long shall those that wicked are
rejoyce triumphingly?
How long shall those men utter forth
& speake things that hard bee?
& shall all such thus boast themselve
that work iniquitee?
Lord, they thy folk in pieces break:
& hrige oppress.
They sly the widdow' & stranger,
& kill the fatherless.
Th Lord they say, yet shall not see:
nor Iacobs God it minde.
Learne vulgr Sos: also yee fooles
when will yee wisdome finde?
Who plns the eare, shll he not heare?
who frmes the eye, not see?
Who heathen smites, shall he not check?
mans teacher, knows not hee?
The Lord doth know the thoughts of man,
that they are very vaine.
Blest man whom thou correctst, o Lord;
& in thy law dost traine.
That thou mayst give him quiet from
dayes of adversity:
untill the pit be digged for
such as doe wickedly.
Because Iehovah he will not
his people cast away,
neither will hee forsake his owne
inheritance for aye.
But judgement unto righteousnes
it shall returne agen:
also all upright ones in heart
they shall pursue it then.
Against the evill doers, who
will up for mee arise?
who will stand up for mee 'gainst them
that work iniquityes?
Had not the Lord me helpt: my soule
had neere in silnce dwel'd.
When a I sayd, my foot slips: Lord,
thy mercy mee upheld.
Amidst the multitude of thougts
of mine within my minde,
still from thy consolations
my soule delight doth finde.
Shall the throne of iniquity
have fellowship with thee:
which frameth molestation
and that by a decree?
They joyntly gathered themselves,
together they withstood
the soule of him that righteous is:
& condemne guiltlesse blood.
But yet Iehovah unto mee
he is a refuge high:
also my God he is the rock
of my hopefull safety.
Their mischief on them he shall bring,
& in their wickedness
he shall them cut off: yea, the Lord
our God shall them suppress.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 95.
DIV2.L: O Come, let us unto the Lord
to the rock of our saving health
Before his presence let us then
For the Lord a great God & great
In whose hands are deepes of the earth,
The sea to him doth appertaine,
& also the drye land is his
for it his hands did fame.
O come, & let us worship give,
he that our maker is, the Lord
Because he is our God, & wee
& of his hands the sheep: to da
if yee his voyce will heare,
Whē mee your fathers tryde, & pro'vd,
Fourty yeares long I griev'd was with
And sayd, this people erre in heart:
my wayes they doe not know.
To whom I sware in wrath: if they

LG.L: SIng to the Lord a new song: sing
all th'earth the Lord unto:
Sing to Iehovah▪ blesse his Name,
still his salvation show.
To'th heathen his glory, to all
people his wonders spread.
For great's the Lord, much to be prays'd,
above all gods in dread.
Because vaine Idols are they all
which heathens Gods doe name:
but yet Iehovah he it is
that did the heavens frame.
Honour & comely majesty
abide before his face:
both fortitude & beauty are
within his holy place.
Yee kindreds of the people all
unto the Lord afford,
glory & mightynes also
give yee unto the Lord.
The glory due unto his name
give yee the Lord unto;
offer yee an oblation,
enter his courts also.
In beauty of his holynes
doe yee the Lord adore:
the universall earth likewise
in feare stand him before.
'Mong heathens say, Iehovah reigns:
the world instablenes
shall be, unmov'd also: he shall
judge fok in righteousnes.
O let the heav'ns ther at b glad,
& let the earth rejoyce:
o let the sea, & 's fullnes
with roaring make a noyse.
O let the field be full of joye,
& all thigs there about:
then all th that be i'th wood
they joyfully shall shout
Before Iehovah, for he comes,
he comes earths judge to bee:
the world with justice, & the folke
judge with his truth shall hee.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 97▪
DIV2.L: THe Lord doth reigne, the earth
let them lift up their voyce.
of all the earth the Lord.
this cause, o Lord, they had,
Yet that doe love the Lord,

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 98. A Psalme
DIV2.L: A New song sing unto the Lord,
his right hand & his holy arme
hath made for to be knowne:
To Isr'ells house of his mercy
the ends of all the earth they have
make yee also a cheerfull sound,
With Harp sing to the Lord; with Harp,
The sea let with her fullnes roare:
O let the flouds clap hands: let hills
Before the Lord, for he doth come
with justice shall he judge the world,

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 99.
DIV2.L: The Lord our God doe you
that to his name send cryes:

LG.L: MAke yee a joyfull sounding noyse
unto Iehovah, all the earth.
Serve yee Iehovah with gladnes:
before his presence come with mirth.
Know, that Iehovah he is God,
who hath us formed it is hee,
& not our selves: his owne people
& sheepe of his pasture are wee.
Enter into his gates with prayse,
into his Courts with thankfllnes:
make yee confession unto him,
& his name reverently blesse.
Because Iehovah he is good,
for evermore is his mercy:
& unto generations all
continue doth his verity.

LG.HEAD: Another of the same.
LG.L: MAke yee a joyfull noyse unto
Iehovah all the earth:
Serve yee Iehovah with gladnes:
before him come with mirth.
Know, that Iehovah he is God,
not wee our selves, but hee
hath made us: his people, & sheep
of his pasture are wee.
O enter yee into his gates
wih prayse, & thankfullnesse
into his Courts: confesse to him,
& his Name doe yee besse.
Because Iehovah he is good,
his bounteous-mercy
is everlasting: & his truth
is to eterity.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 101. A psalme of David.
DIV2.L: Lod, I will sing to thee.
I'le wisely doe in perfect way:
when wilt thou come to mee?
I will in midst of my house walk
I will not set before mine eyes
I hate their worke that turne aside,
it shall not cleave me to.
Froward in heart from mee shall part,
I'le cut him off, that slaundereth
I cannot beare the proud in hearr,
Vpon the faithfull in the land
mine eyes shall be, that they
may dwell with mee: he shall mee serve
Hee that a worker is of guile,
shall not in my house dwell:
before mine eyes he shall not be
Yea, all the wicked of the land
to cutt off from Gods citty all

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 102 A prayer of the afflicted when he is over∣whelmed, & poureth out his complaint before the Lord.

LG.L: LORD, heare my supplication,
& let my cry come thee unto:
I'th day when trouble is on mee
thy face hide not away mee fro:
Thine eare to mee doe thou incline,
i'th day I cry, soone answer mee:
For as the smoake my dayes consume,
& like an hearth my bones burnt bee.
My heart is smote, & dryde like grasse,
that I to eate my bread forget:
By reason of my groanings voyce
my bones unto my skin are set.
Like Pelican in wildernes,
like Owle in desart so am I:
I watch, & like a sparrow am
on house top solitarily.
Mine enemies daily mee reproach:
'gainst mee they rage, 'gainst mee they sweare:
That I doe ashes eate for bread:
& mixe my drink with weeping-teare.
By reason of thy fervent wrath
& of thy vehement-disdaine:
for thou hast high advanced mee,
& thou hast cast mee downe againe.
My dayes as shaddow that decline:
& like the withered grasse am I.
But thou, Lord, dost abide for aye:
& thy Name to eternity.
Thou wilt arise, & wilt shew forth
thy tender-mercy on Sion:
for it is time to favour her,
yea the set time is now come on.
For in her stones thy servants doe
take plesure, & her dust pitty.
And heathens shall the Lords Name feare.
& all Kings of th'earth thy glory.
When as the Lord shall Sion build
hee in his glory shall appeare.
The poor's petition hee'l regard,
& hee will not despise their pray'r.
This shall in writing be inroll'd
for the succeeding-after-race:
that people also which shall bee
created, they the Lord may prayse.
For from his Sanctuary high
from heavn's the Lord the earth doth see:
To heare the groanes of prisoners:
to loose them that deaths children bee.
The Lords prayse in Ierusalem:
his Name in Sion to record.
when people are together met,
& Kingdomes for to serve the Lord.
He weakned hath i'th way my strength,
& shortened my dayes hath hee.
I say, in middst of my dayes
my God doe not away take mee:
Thy yeares throughout all ages are.
Thou hst the earth's foundation layd
for elder time: & heavens bee
the work which thine owne hands have mae.
They perish shall, but thou shlt stand:
they all as garments shall decay:
& as a wering vstiment
thou shalt thē change, & chang'd are they.
But thou art ev'n the same: thy yeares
they never shall consumed bee.
Thy servants children shall abide,
& their seed stablisht before thee.
O Thou my soule, Iehovah blesse,
& all things that in me
most inward are, in humblenes
his Holy-Name blesse ye
The Lord blesse in humility,
o thou my soule: also
put not out of thy memory
all's bounties, thee unto.
For hee it is who pardoneth
all thine iniquityes:
he it is also who healeth
all thine infirmityes.
Who thy life from destruction
redeems: who crowneth thee
with his tender compassion
& kinde benignitee.
Who with good things abundantlee
doth satisfie thy mouth:
so that like as the Eagles bee
renewed is thy youth.
The Lord doth judgement & justice
for all oppressed ones.
To Moses shew'd those wayes of his:
his acts to Isr'ells sonnes.
The Lord is mercifull also
hee's vry gracious:
and unto anger hee is slow,
in mercy plenteous.
Contention he will not maintaine
to perpetuity:
nor he his anger will retaine
unto eternity.
According to our sins likewise
to us hee hath not done:
nor hath he our iniquityes
rewarded us upon.
Because even as the heavens are
in height the earh above:
so toward them that doe him feare
confirmed is his love.
Like as the East & West they are
farre in their distances:
he hath remov'd away so far
from us our trespasses.
A fathers pitty like unto,
which he his sonnes doth beare:
like pitty doth Iehovah show
to them that doe him feare.
For he doth know this frame of ours:
he minds that dust wee bee.
Mans dayes are like the grasse: like flowrs
in field, so flourisheth hee.
For over it the winde doth passe,
& it away doth goe;
also the place wheras it was
noe longer shall it know.
But yet Gods mercy ever is,
shall be & ye hath been
to them tht feare him; and's justice
unto childrens children.
To such as keepe his covenant,
that doe in minde up lay
the charge of his commandement
that it they may obey.
The Lord hath in the heavens hye
established his throne:
and over all his Royallty
doth beare dominion.
O yee his Angells that excell
in strngth, blesse yee the Lord,
that doe his word, that harken well
unto the voyce of 's word.
All yee that are the Lords armies,
o blesse Iehovah stll:
& all yee ministers of his,
his pleasure that fullfill.
Yea, all his works in places all
of his dominion,
blesse yee Iehovh o my Soul,
Iehovah blesse alone.
THe Lord blesse, o my Soule, o Lord
my God, exceedigly
great art thou: thou with honour art
cloath'd & with maisy.
Who dost thy selfe with light, as if
it were a garment cover:
who like unto a curtaine dost
the heavens stretch all over.
Who of his chambers layes the beames
ith waters, & hee makes
the cloudes his Charrets, & his way
on wings of winde hee takes.
His Angells Spirits, his ministers
who makes a fiery flame.
who earths foundations layd, that ne're
should be remov'd the same.
Thou with the deep (as with a robe)
didst cover the dry land:
above the places mountainous
the waters they did stand.
When as that thou rebukedst them
away then fled they fast:
they also at thy thunders voyce
with speed away doe hast.
Vp by the mountaines they asscend:
downe by the valleys go,
the place which thou didst found for them
untill they come unto.
Thou hast to them a bound prefixt
which they may not passe over:
so that they might noe more returne
againe the earth to cover.
who springs into the valleys sends,
which run among the hills.
whence all beasts of the field have drink:
wilde asses drink their fills.
Heavns fowles dwell by them, which do sing
among the sprigs with mirth.
Hee waters from his lofs the hills:
thy works fruit fill the earth.
For beasts hee makes the grasse to grow,
herbs also for mans good:
that hee may bring out of the earth
what may be for their food:
Wine also tht mans heart may glad,
& oyle their face to bright:
and bread which to the heart of man
may it supply with might.
Gods trees are sappy: his planted
Cedars of Lebanon:
Where birds doe nest: as for the Storke,
Firres are her mansion.
The wilde Goates refuge are the hills:
rocks Conies doe inclose.
The Moone hee hath for seasons set,
the Sun his setting knows.
Thou makest darknes, & 'tis night:
when wood beasts creep out all.
After their prey young Lions roare:
from God for food hey call.
The Sun doth rise, then in their dennes
they couch, when gone aside.
Man to his work & labour goes,
untill the ev'ning-tide.
O Lord, how many are thy works!
all of them thou hast wrought
in wisdome: with thy plenteous store
the earth is fully fraught.
So is this great & spatious sea,
wherin things creeping bee
beyond all number: beasts of small
& of great quantitee.
There goe the ships: Leviathan,
therin thou madst to play.
These all wayt on thee, that their meate
in their time give thou may.
They gather what thou givest them:
thy hand thou op'nest wide,
& they with such things as are good
are fully satisfyde.
Thou hid'st thy face, they troubled are,
their breath thou tak'st away,
then doe they dye: also returne
unto their dust doe they.
They are created, when thou makst
thy spirit forth to go:
thou of the earth dost make the ace
to be renew'd also.
The glory of Iehovah shall
for evermore indure:
in his owne works Iehovah shall
joyfully take pleasure.
The earth doth tremble, when that hee
upon the same doth look,
the mountaines he doth touch, likewise
they therupon do smoak.
Full sweet my meditation
concerning him shall be:
so that I in Iehovah will
rejoyce exceedinglee.
Let sinners be consum'd from th'earth,
& wicked be no more:
blesse thou Iehovah, o my soule,
prayse yee the Lord therefore.
O Prayse the Lord, call on his Name.
'mong people shew his facts.
Sing unto him, sing psalmes to him:
talk of all's wondrous acts.
Let their hearts joy, that seek the Lord:
boast in his Holy-Name.
The Lord seek, & his strengh: his face
alwayes seek yee the same.
Those admirable works that hee
hath done remember you:
his wonders, & the judgements which
doe from his mouth issu.
O yee his servant Abrahams seed:
sonnes of chose Iacob yee.
He is the Lord our God: in all
the earth his judgements bee.
His Covenant for evermore,
and his comanded word,
a thousand generations to
he doth in minde record,
Which he with Abraham made, and's oath
to Isack. Made it fast,
a law to Iacob: & Isr'ell
a Cov'nant aye to last.
He sayd, I'le give thee Canans land:
by lot, heirs to be there.
When few, yea very few in count
and strangers in't they were;
When they did from one nation
unto another pass:
when from one Kingdome their goings
to other people was,
He suffred none to doe them wrong:
Kings checkt he for their sake:
Touch not mine oynted ones; none ill
unto my Prophets make.
He cal'd for Famine on the land,
all staffe of bread brake hee.
Before them sent a man: Ioseph
sold for a slave to bee.
Whose feet they did with fetters hur:
in yr'n his soule did lye.
Vntill the time that his word came:
the Lords word did him trye.
The King the peoples Ruler sent,
loos'd him & let him go.
He made him Lord of all his house:
of all's wealth ruler too:
At's will to binde his Peers: & teach
his Ancients skill. Then came
Isr'ell to Egypt: & Iacob
sojourn'd i'th land of Ham.
He much increast his folk: & made
them stronger then their foe,
Their heart he turn'd his folk: to hate:
to's servants craft to show.
Mose his servant he did send:
& Aaron whom he chose.
His signes & wonders them amongst,
they in Hams land disclose.
Hee darknes sent, & made it dark:
nor did they's word gain-say.
Hee turn'd their waters into bloud:
& he their fish did sly.
Great store of Frogs their land brought forth
in chambers of their Kings.
He spake, there came mixt swarmes, & lice
in all their coasts he brings.
He gave them haile for raine: & in
their land fires flme did make.
And smote their Vines & their Figtree:
& their coast-tres he brake.
He spake, & then the Locusts came:
& Caterpillars, such
the number of them was as none
could reckon up how much,
And ate all their lands herbs: & did
fruit of their ground devoure.
All first borne in their land he smot:
the chief of all their powre.
With silver also & with gold
he them from thence did bring:
& among all their tribes there was
not any one weakling.
Egypt was glad when out they went:
for on them fell their dread.
A cloud for cov'ring, & a fire
to light the night he spred.
They askt, & he brought quailes: did them
with heav'ns bread satisfy,
He op't the rock and waters flow'd:
flouds ran in places dry.
For on his holy promise, hee
and's servant Abraham thought.
With joye his people, and with songs
forth he his hosen brought.
He of the heathen people did
the land on them bestow:
the labour of the people they
inherited also.
To this intent that his statutes
they might observe alwayes:
also that they his lawes might keepe.
doe yee Ihovah prayse.
PRayse yee the Lord, o to the Lord
give thanks, for good is hee:
for his mercy continued is
to perpetuitee.
Who can the Lords strong acts foth tell?
or all his prayse display?
Blest they that judgement keep: & wh
doth righteousnes alway.
With favour of thy people, Lord,
doe thou remember mee:
and mee with that salvation
visit which is of thee:
To see thy chosens good, to joy
in gladnes of thy nation:
that with thine owne inheritance
I might have exultation.
As our fore-fathers so have wee
sinned erroniously:
wee practis'd have iniquity,
wee have done wickedly.
Our fathers did not understand
thy wonders in Egypt,
nor was thy mercyes multitude
in their remembrance kept:
But at the sea at the red sea
vext him. Yet for his owne
Names sake he av'd them that he migh
his mighty powre make knowne.
The red sea also he rebuk't,
and dryed up it was:
so that as through the wildernes,
through depths he made them pass.
And from the hand of him that did
them hate, he set them fre:
and them redeemed from his hand
th was their enemee.
The waters covered their foes:
of them there was left none.
They did believe his word; they sang
his prayses therupon.
They soone forgot his words; nor would
they for his counsell stay:
But much i'th wildernes did lust;
i'th desart God tryde they.
And he their suite them gave; but sent
leannes their soule into.
They envi'd Moses in the camp,
Aaron Gods Saint also.
The opned earth, Dathan devour'd;
and hid Abirams troup.
And fire was kindled in their rout:
flame burnt the wicked up.
In Horeb made a calfe; also
molt image worshipt they.
They chang'd their glory to be like,
an oxe that eateth hay.
They God forgot their saviour; which
in Egipt did great acts:
Works wondrous in the land of Ham:
by th'red sea dreadfull facts.
And sayd, he would them waste; had not
Moses stood (whom he chose)
'fore him i'th breach▪ to turne his wrath,
lest that hee should waste those.
Yet they despis'd the pleasant land:
nor did believe his word:
But murmur'd in their tents: the voyce
they heard not of the Lord.
To make them fall i'th desart then,
'gainst them he lift his hands.
'Mongst nations eke to fell their seed,
and scatter them i'th lands.
And to Baal-Peor they joyn'd themselves:
ate offrings of the dead.
Their works his wrath did thus provoake:
the plague amongst them spread.
Then Phineas rose, & judgement did:
and so the plague did stay.
Which justice to him counted was:
to age and age for aye.
At th'waters of contention
they angred him also:
so that with Moses for their sakes,
it very ill did go:
Because his spirit they provoakt:
with's lips to speake rashly.
The nations as the Lord them charg'd▪
they stroyd not utterly:
But were amongst the Heathen mixt,
and learn'd their works to do:
And did their Idols serve; which them
became a snare unto.
Yea, unto divills, they their sonnes
and daughters offered·
And guiltlesse bloud, bloud of their sons
& of their daughters shed,
Whom unto Canans Idols they
offred in sacrifice:
the land with bloud abundantly
polluted was likewise.
Thus with the works were they defylde
which they themselves had done:
and they did goe a whoring with
inventions of their owne:
Therefore against his folk the wrath
was kindled of the Lord:
so that he the inheritance
which was his owne abhorr'd.
And he gave them to heathens hand;
their haters their lords were.
Their foes thral'd them; under their hand
made them the yoake to beare.
Oft he deliverd them; but they
provoakt him bitterly
with their counell, & were brought low
for their iniquity.
Yet, he regarded their distresse;
when he did heare their plaint.
And he did to remembrance call
for them his Covenant:
And in hi many mercyes did
repent. And made them bee
pitty'd of all that led them forth
into captivitee.
Save us, o Lord our God, & us
from heathens gath'ring rayse
to give thanks to thy Holy-Name:
to triumph in thy prayse.
The Lord the God of Israell
from aye to aye blest bee:
and let all people say Amen.
o prayse Iehovah yee.
O Give yee thanks unto the Lord,
because that good is hee:
because his loving kindenes lasts
to perpetuitee.
So let the Lords redeem'd say: whom
hee freed from th'enemies hands:
And gathred them from East, & West,
from South, & Northerne lands.
I'th desart, in a desart way
they wandred: no towne finde,
to dwell in. Hungry & thirsty:
their soule within them pinde.
Then did they to Iehovah cry
when they were in distresse:
who did them set at liberty
out of their anguishes.
In such a way that was most right
he led them forth also:
that to a citty which they might
inhabit they might go.
O that men would Iehovah prayse
for his great goodnes then:
& for his workings wonderfull
unto the sonnes of men.
Because that he the longing soule
doth throughly satisfy:
the hungry soule he also fills
with good abundantly.
Such as in darknes' and within
the shade of death abide;
who are in sore affliction,
also in yron tyde:
By reason that against the words
of God they did rebell;
also of him that is most high
contemned the counsell.
Therefore with molestation
hee did bring downe their heart:
downe did they fall, & none their was
could help to them impart.
Then did they to Iehovah cry
when they were in distress:
who did them set at liberty
out of their anguishes.
He did them out of darknes bring,
also deaths shade from under:
as for the bands that they were in
he did them break asunder.
O that men would Iehovah prayse
for his great goodnes then:
and for his workings wonderfull
unto the sonnes of men.
For he hath all to shivers broke
the gates that were of brasse:
& hee asunder cut each barre
that made of yron was.
For their transgressions & their sins,
fooles doe affliction beare.
All kinde of meate their soule abhorres:
to deaths gate they draw neare.
Then did they to Iehovah cry
when they were in distres▪
who did them set at liberty
out of their anguishes.
He, sent his word, & therewithall
healing to them he gave:
from out of their destructions
he did them also save.
O that men would Iehovah prayse,
for his great goodnes then:
& for his workings wonderfull
unto the sons of men.
And sacrifices sacrifice
let them of thanksgiving:
& while his works they doe declare
let them for gladnes sing.
They that goe downe to'th sea in ships:
their busines there to doo
in waters great. The Lords work see,
it'h deep his wonders too.
Because that he the stormy winde
commandeth to arise:
which lifteth up the waves therof,
They mount up to the skyes:
Downe goe they to the depths againe,
their soule with ill doth quaile.
They reele, & stagger, drunkard like,
and all their witt doth faile.
Then did they to Iehovah cry
when they were in distress:
and therupon he bringeth them
out of their anguishes.
Hee makes the storme a calme: so that
the waves therof are still.
Their rest then glads them; he them brings
to'th hav'n which they did will.
O that men would Iehovah prayse
for his great goodnes then:
& for his workings wonderfull
unto the sons of men.
Also within the peoples Church
him let them highly rayse:
where Elders are assembled, there
him also let them prayse.
He rivers to a desart turnes,
to drought the springing well:
A fruitfull soyle to barrennes;
for their sin there that dwell.
The desart to a poole he turnes;
and dry ground to a spring.
Seates there the hungry; who prepare
their towne of habiting,
Vineyards there also for to plant,
also to sow the field;
which may unto them fruitfull things▪
of much revenue yield.
Also he blesseth them, so that
they greatly are increast:
and for to be diminished
he suffers not their beast.
Againe they are diminished
& they are brought downe low,
by reason of their pressing-streights,
affliction & sorrow.
On Princes he contempt doth powre;
and causeth them to stray
i'th solitary wildernes,
wherin there is no way.
Yet hee out of affliction
doth make the poore to rise▪
& like as if it were a flock
doth make him families.
The righteous shall it behold,
and he shall joyfull bee:
in silence stop her mouth also
shall all iniquitee.
Who so is wise, & who so will
these things attentive learne:
the loving-kindenes of the Lord
they clearely shall discerne.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 108. A song or psalme of David.

LG.L: O GOD, my heart's fixt, I'le sing; prayse
sing ev'n with my glory.
Awake thou Psaltery & Harp;
I will awake early.
O thou Iehovah, thee will I
the people prayse among:
within the midst of nations
thee will I prayse with song.
For o're the heav'ns thy mercys great;
to'th skyes thy truth doth mount.
Or'e heav'ns o God, be lift, all earth
let thy glory surmount:
That thy beloved people may
be set at libertee:
with thy right hand salvation give,
& doe thou answer mee.
God hath in his owne holines
spoken, rjoyce I shall:
of Shechem I'le division make;
& mete our Succoths vale.
Mine Gilead, mine Manasseh is,
& Ephraim also hee
is of my head the strength: Iudah
shall my law-giver bee.
Moab my wash-pot, I will cast
over Edom my shoo:
I'le make a shout triumphantly
over Philistia too.
Who is it that will bring me to
the citty fortifyde?
who is it that into Edom
will be to mee a guide?
Wilt not thou doe this thing, o God,
who didst us cast thee fro?
& likewise wilt thou o God,
forth with our armies go?
From trouble give us help; for vaine
is mans salvation.
Through God wee shall do valiantly;
for hee'l our foes tread downe.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 109. To the chief musician, a psalme of David.

LG.L: GOD of my prayse, hold not thy peace,
For mouth of the wicked,
& mouth of the deceitfull are
against mee opened:
Gainst mee they speake with lying tongue.
And compasse mee about
with words of hate; & mee against
without a cause they fought.
They for my love mine enemies are:
but I my prayer make.
And ill for good rewarded mee;
& hate for my loves sake.
A wicked person over him
doe thou make for to sit,
also at his right hand doe thou
let Satan stand at it.
When he is judged, let him then
condemned be therin:
and let the prayr that hee doth make.
be turned into sin.
Few let his dayes bee: & let his
office another take.
His children let be fatherlesse,
and's wife a widow make.
Let's children still be vagabonds,
begge they their bread also:
out of their places desolate
let them a seeking go
Yea, let th'extortioner catch all
that doth to him pertaine:
and let the stranger spoyle what he
did by his labour gaine.
Let there not any bee that may
mercy to him expresse:
nor any one that favour may
his children fatherlesse.
The ishue also let thou be
cut off that from him came:
it'h following generation
out blotted be his name.
Remembred with the Lord be his
fathers iniquitee:
and of his mother never let
the sin out blotted bee.
Before Iehovah let them bee
continually put:
that from out of the earth he may
the mem'ry of them cut.
Because that he remembred not
compassion to impart,
but did pursue the needy poore:
to slay the broke in heart.
As he did cursing love, so let
cursing unto him come:
as he did not in blessing joy,
so be it far him from.
With cursing like a robe as hee
cloath'd him: so let it go
like water to his bowels, and
like oyle his bones into.
Garment like let it to him be,
himselfe for to aray:
and for a girdle, wherewith hee
may gird himselfe alway.
Thus let mine adversaryes bee
rewarded from the Lord:
also of them against my soule
that speak an evil word.
But God the Lord, for thy Names sake,
o doe thou well for mee:
because thy mercy it is good,
o doe thou set mee free.
For poore & needy I: in mee
my heart's wounded also.
Like falling shade I passe▪ I'me tost
Locust like to & fro.
Through fasts my knees are weak: my flesh
it's fatnes doth forsake.
And I am their reproach: they look
at mee, their heads they shake.
Help mee, o Lord my God: after
thy mercy save thou mee:
That they may know this is thy hand:
Lord that i'ts done by thee.
Let them curse, but o doe thou blesse;
when as that they arise
let them be shamed, thy servant
let him rejoyce likewise.
Mine adversaryes o let them
with shame be cloath'd upon:
& themselves cloath as with a cloak
with their confusion.
I'le to Iehovah with my mouth
give thanks exceedingly:
yea him among the multitude
with prayse I'le glorify.
For hee shall stand at right hand of
the poore & needy one:
from those that doe condemne his soule
to give salvation.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 110. A psalme of David.
DIV2.L: THe Lord did say unto my Lord,
sit thou at my right hand:
till I thine enemies make a stoole
The Lord the rod shall of thy strength
Willing thy folk in thy dayes powre,
from mornings womb; thou hast the de
thou art a Priest for aye:
after the order that I of
The Lord who is at thy right hand.
in that same day wherin that hee
Hee shall among the heathen judge,
he shall strike through the head.
Out of the torrent he shall drink
because of this therefore hee shall
lift up his head on hye.

LG.L: PRayse yee the Lord; with my whole heart
Iehovah prayse will I:
i'th private meetings of th'upright,
and publicke assembly.
Great are the Lords works: sought of all
that in them have pleasure.
Comely & glorious is his work:
aye doth his justice dure.
To be remembred he hath made
his doings merveilous:
full of compassion is the Lord
as well as gracious.
Meate hath hee given unto them
that fearers of him be:
he evermore his covenant
doth keepe in memoree:
The power of his works hee did
unto his people show:
that he the heathens heritage
upon them might bestow.
Both verity & judgement are
the working of his hands:
yea very faithfull also are
each one of his commands.
For ever & for evermore
they stand in stablenes:
yea they are done in verity
also in uprightnes·
Redemption to his folk he sent,
that covenant of his
for aye he hath ordaind: holy
and reverend his Name is.
Of wisdome the begining is
Iehovahs feare: all they
that doe his will have prudence good.
his prayse indures for aye.
PRayse yee the Lord. blest is the man
that doth Iehovah feare,
that doth in his commandements
his spirit greatly cheare.
The very mighty upon earth
shall be that are his seed:
they also shall be blessed that
from th' upright doe proceed.
And there shall be within his house
both wealth & much rich store:
his righteousnes it also doth
indure for evermore.
In midst of darknes there doth light
to upright ones arise:
both gracious, & pittyfull,
righteous he is likewise▪
A good man hee doth favour show
& ready is to lend:
and with descretion his affayres
he caryes to an end.
That man shall not assuredly
for ever moved bee:
the righteous man he shall be had
in lasting memoree.
By evill tydings that he heares
he shall not be afrayd:
his trust he putting in the Lord.
his heart is fimly stayd.
His heart is sure established,
feare shall not him surprise,
untill he see what hee desires
upon his enemies.
He hath disperst, hath giv'n to poore:
his justice constantly
indureth: & his horne shall be
with honour lifed hye.
The wicked shall see, & be griev'd;
gnash with his teeth shall hee
and melt away: and their desire
shall faile that wicked be▪

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 113.
DIV2.L: THe Lord prayse yee, prayse yee the Lord
From rising to the setting sun:
the Lords Name's to be praysd.
The Lord al nations is above:
Who is like to, the Lord our God?
Who humble doth himselfe to view.
in heav'n, in earth as well.
The needy from the dust he lifts:
the poore lifts from the dung.
That hee with princes may him set:
The barren woman he doth make

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 114.
DIV2.L: and Iacobs house from a people
that were of a strange tongue:
The sea it saw, & fled: Iordane
the litle hills also they did
Thou sea what made thee flye?
Yee mountaines that yee skipt like ram:
The rock who turnes to waters lake:
springs he from flint sends thence.

LG.L: NOt to us, not unto us, Lord,
but glory to ty Name afford:
for thy mercy, for thy truths sake.
The heathen wherefore should they say:
where is their God now gone away?
But heavn's our God his seat doth make:
Hee hath done whatsoe're he would.
Their Idols are silver & gold:
the handy work of men they were.
Mouths have they, speachlesse yet they be:
eyes have they, but they doe not see.
Eares have they but they doe not heare:
Noses have they, but doe not smell.
Hands have they, but cannot handell,
feet have they but they doe not go:
And though their throat they never spake.
Like them are they, that doe them make:
& all that trust in them are so.
Trust in the Lord o Israell,
he is their help, their shield as well.
O Arons house the Lord trust yee:
Hee is their help, & hee their shield.
Who feare the Lord, trust to him yield:
their help also their shield is hee.
The Lord hath mindefull been of us,
he'le blesse us, he'le blesse Isr'ells house:
blessing he'le Arons house afford.
He'le blesse Gods fearers: great & small.
You & your sons, the Lord much shall
increase still. You blest of the Lord
which heav'n & earth made. Heav'ns heav'ns-bee
the Lords: but th'earth mens sons gives hee.
The Lords prayse dead doe not afford:
Nor any that to silence bow.
But wee will blesse the Lord both now
and ever henceforth. prayse the Lord.
I Love the Lord, because he doth
my voice & prayer heare.
And in my dayes will call, because
he bow'd to mee his eare.
The pangs of death on ev'ry side
about beset mee round:
the paines of hell 'gate hold on mee,
distresse & griefe I found.
Vpon Iehovahs Name therefore
I called, & did say,
deliver thou my soule, o Lord,
I doe thee humbly pray.
Gracious the Lord & just, our God
is mercifull also.
The Lord the simple keeps: & hee
sav'd mee when I was low.
O thou my soule doe thou returne
unto thy quiet rest:
because the Lord to thee himselfe
hath bounteously exprest.
For thou hast freed my soule from death,
mine eyes from teares, from fall
my feet. Before the Lord i'th land
of living walk I shall.
I did believe, therefore I spake:
afflicted much was I.
That every man a lyar is
I did say hastily.
What shall I render to the Lord,
to mee for's benfits all.
I'le take the cup of saving health
& on the Lords Name call.
In presence now of all his folk,
I'le pay the Lord my vowes.
Of his Saints, in Iehovahs sight
the death is pretious.
I am thy servant, truly Lord
thine owne servant am I:
I am the son of thy hand-maide,
my bands thou didst untye.
Of thanksgiving the sacrifice
offer to thee I will:
Iehovahs Name I earnestly
will call upon it still.
Vnto Iehovah I will pay
the vowes were made by mee,
now in the presence of all them
that his owne people bee.
Within the Courts of the Lords house,
ev'n in the midst of thee
o thou citty Ierusalem:
o prayse Iehovah yee.
AL nations, prayse the Lord; him prayse
all people. For his mercies bee
great toward us: also alwayes
the Lords truth lasts. the Lord prayse yee.

LG.HEAD: Another of the same.
LG.L: AL nations, prayse the Lord; all folk
prayse him. For his mercee
is great to us; & the Lords truth
aye lasts. the Lord prayse yee.
O Give yee thnks unto the Lord,
because that good is hee;
because his loving kindenes lasts
to perpetuitee.
For ever that his mercie lasts
let Israell now say.
Let Arons house now say, that his
mercie indures for aye.
Likewise let them now say, who of
Iehovah fearers bee;
his loving kindenes that it lasts
to perpetuitee.
I did lift up my voice to God
from out of streitnes great;
the Lord mee answerd, & mee plac't
in an inlarged seat.
The Lord's for mee, I will not feare
what man can doe to mee.
Iehovah takes my part with them
that of mee helpers bee:
Therefore upon them that mee hate
my wishes see shall I.
'Tis better to trust in the Lord:
then on man to rely.
'Tis better to trust on the Lord:
then trust in Princes put.
All nations compast mee, but them
in Gods Name I'le off cut.
They compast mee about, yea they
mee compassed about:
but in Iehovahs Name I will
them utterly root out.
They compast mee like Bees, are quencht
like as of thornes the flame:
but I will utterly destroy
them in Iehovahs Name.
Thou didst thrust sore to make mee fall:
the Lord yet helped mee.
The Lord my fortitude & song:
& saving health is hee.
The tabernacles of the just
the voice of joye afford
& of salvation: strongly works
the right hand of the Lord.
The right hand of Iehovah is
exalted up on hye:
the right hand of Iehovah is
a working valiantly.
I shall not dye, but live: & tell
what things the Lord worketh.
The Lord did sorely chasten mee:
but gave mee not to death.
O set wide open unto mee
the gates of righteousnes:
I will goe into them, & will
Iehovahs praise confess.
This same Iehovahs gate at which
the just shall enter in.
I'le praise thee, for thou hast mee heard,
and hast my safety bin.
The stone which builders did refuse
head corner stone now lyes.
This is the doing of the Lord:
it's wondrous in our eyes,
This is the very day the which
Iehovah hee hath made:
wee will exceedingly rejoyce,
& in it will be glad.
Iehovah I doe thee beseech,
salvation now afford:
I humbly thee intreat, now send
prosperity, o Lord.
Hee that comes in Iehovahs Name
o let him blessed bee:
out of Iehovahs house to you
a blesing wish doe wee.
God he Iehovah is, and hee
light unto us affords:
the sacrifices binde unto
the altars hornes with cords.
Thou art my God, & I'le thee prayse,
my God I'le set thee hye.
O prayse the Lord, for he is good,
and aye lasts his mercy.

LG.HEAD: (1) Aleph
LG.L: ALL-blest are men upright of way:
walk in Iehovahs law who do.
Blest such as doe his records keepe:
with their whole heart him seek also.
And that work no iniquitie:
but in his wayes doe walke indeed.
Thou hast giv'n charge, with diligence
unto thy precepts to give hd.
Ah that to keepe thy statutes: so
my wayes addressed were by thee.
When I respect thy preceps all,
then shall I not ashamed be.
Whē I thy righteous judgements learne
with hearts uprightnes I'le thee prayse.
Forsake thou mee not utterly:
I will observe thy statute-wayes.

LG.HEAD: (2) Beth
LG.L: By what may 'young man cleanse his way?
by heeding it as thy word guides.
With my whole heart thee have I sought:
thy lawes let mee not goe besides.
I in my heart thy word have hid:
that I might not against thee sin.
Thou o Iehovah, blessed art:
thine owne statutes instruct mee in.
All the just judgements of thy mouth
declared with my lips have I.
I in thy testimonyes way
joy more then in all rich plenty.
In thy precepts I'le meditate:
and have respect unto thy wayes▪
My selfe I'le solace in thy lawes:
and not forget what thy word sayes.

LG.HEAD: (3) Gimel
LG.L: Confer this grace thy servant to,
that I may live thy word to keep.
Vnveile mine eyes, that I may see
out of thy law the wonders deep.
I am a stranger in the earth:
do not thy precepts from me hide.
My soule is broken with desire
unto thy judgements time & tide.
Thou hast rebuk'd the proud, acust
which doe frō thy commandments swerve.
Roll off from mee reproach & scorne:
for I thy records doe observe.
Ev'n Princes sate & 'gainst mee spake;
but on thy lawes thy servant mus'd.
Also thy records are my joyes:
and for men of my counsell us'd.

LG.HEAD: (4) Daleth
LG.L: Downe to the dust my soule cleav, s fast:
o quicken mee after thy word.
I show'd my wayes & thou mee heardst:
thy statutes learning mee afford.
Thy precepts way make mee to know:
so I'le muse on thy wondrous wayes.
My soule doth melt for heavines:
according to thy word mee rayse.
The way of lying from mee take:
and thy law grant mee graciously.
The way of truth I chosen have:
thy judgements 'fore mee layd have I.
Thy testimonies cleave I to;
o ord, on mee shame do not cast.
Thn shall I run thy precepts way,
when thou mine heart enlarged hast.

LG.HEAD: (5) He·
LG.L: Enforme mee Lord, in thy laws path;
and I will keep it to the end.
Skill give mee, & thy law I'le keep:
yea with my whole heart it attend.
Cause mee to tread thy precepts path;
because therin delight I do.
Vnto thy records bend my heart;
& covetousnes not unto.
From vaine sights turne away mine eyes:
and in thy way make mee to live.
Confirme thy word thy servant to,
who to thy feare himselfe doth give.
My slander which I feare remove;
because thy judgements good they bee▪
Loe for thy precepts I have lon'gd:
o in thy justice quicken mee.

LG.HEAD: (6) Vau.
LG.L: Finde mee out let thy mercies Lord:
thy saving health as thou hast sayd.
So I my taunters answer shall,
for on thy word my hope is stayd.
Nor truths-word quite frō my mouth take:
because thy judgements I attend.
So I thy law shall alway keep,
to everlasting without end.
And I will walk at libertie,
because I doe thy precepts seek.
Nor will I blush, when before Kings
I of thy testimonies speak.
In thy commands, which I have lov'd,
also my selfe delight I will.
And lift my hands to thy commands
belov'd: & minde thy statutes still.

LG.HEAD: (7) Sajin.
LG.L: Good to thy servant make the word,
on which to hope thou didst mee give.
This was my comfort in my griefe,
because thy word doth make mee live.
The proud have much derided mee:
yet have I not thy law declinde.
Thy judgements Lord, that are of old,
I did recall, & comfort finde.
Horrour hath taken hold on mee:
for lewd men that thy law forsake.
I, in my pilgrimages house,
of thy statutes my songs doe make.
By night remembred I thy Name,
o Lord: & I thy law observe.
This hath been unto mee, because
I from thy precepts did not swerve.

LG.HEAD: (8) Heh.
LG.L: Hee, ev'n the Lord, my portion is,
I said that I would keep thy word.
With my whole heart thy face I begg'd:
thy promis'd mercies mee afford.
I thought upon my waies, & turn'd
my feet into thy testaments.
I hasted, & made no delaies
to keepe with heed thy commandments.
The bands of wicked men mee robb'd:
of thy law I am not mindeless.
Ile rise at midnight thee to praise;
for judgements of thy righteousnes.
Companion am I to all them,
that feare thee, & thy laws doe heed.
Thy mercie fills the earth, o Lord:
teach mee the lawes thou hast decreed.

LG.HEAD: (9) Teth.
LG.L: Iehovah, with thy servant thou
after thy word, right-well hast done.
Good taste & knowledge, teach thou m,
for I believe thy precepts on.
Before I was chastis'd, I stray'd:
but I thy word observ'd have now.
Thou art good, & art doing good:
thy statutes teach mee, oh doe thou.
The proud against mee forg'd a lye:
thy laws I'le keepe with my hearts-might.
The heart of them is fat as grease:
but in thy law I doe delight.
It's good for mee, I was chastis'd:
that so thy statutes learne I should.
Better to mee is thy mouths-law,
then thousands of silver & gold.

LG.HEAD: (10) Iod.
LG.L: Know make mee, & I'le learn thy lawes:
thy hands mee formed have, & made.
Who feare thee, mee shall see, & joy:
because hope in thy word I had.
Thy judgements Lord, I know are just;
& faithfully thou chastnedst mee.
As thou hast to thy servant spoke,
now let thy grace my comfort bee.
Send mee thy grace, that I may live;
for thy law as my joy I chue.
Shame proud ones, that mee falsly wrong:
but I will in thy precepts muse.
Let them that feare thee turne to mee;
and such as have thy records knowne.
Let my heart bee in thy lawes sound
that so I shame may suffer none.

LG.HEAD: (11) Caph.
LG.L: Look for thy word I doe, when as
my soule doth faint for help from thee.
Mine eies have failed for thy word,
saying, when wilt thou comfort mee?
I like a smoake-dride-bottle am;
yet doe I not thy laws forgoe.
what are thy servants daies? when wilt
on my pursuers judgement doe?
The proud have digged pits for mee,
which doe not unto thy law sute.
All thy comands are truth▪ help mee,
they wrongfully mee persecute.
They nigh had wasted mee on earth,
but I thy laws did not forsake.
To keep the records of thy mouth,
mee in thy mecie lively make.

LG.HEAD: (12) Lamed.
LG.L: Made fast i'th heavens is thy word,
o Lord, for ever to endure.
From age to age thy faithfullnes:
thou form'dst the earth, & it stands-sure.
As thou ordain'dst, they still abide;
for all are servants thee unto.
Had not thy law been my delight:
Then had I perisht in my wo.
Thy statutes I will ne're forget:
because by them thou quicknedst mee.
Thine owne am I, save mee, because
I sought thy precepts studioulee.
The wicked watch mee, mee to stroy:
but I thy testimonies minde.
Of all perfection, end I see:
but very large thy law I finde.

LG.HEAD: (13) Mem.
LG.L: Now how much doe I love thy law?
it is my study all the day.
Thou mad'st mee wiser then my foes
by thy rule: for it's with mee aye.
I'me wiser then my teachers all▪
for thy records my study are.
I more then ancients understand;
because I kept thy laws with care.
From each ill path my feet I stay'd:
that so I might thy word observe.
Becuse thou hast instructed mee,
I did not from thy judgements swerve.
How sweet are thy words to my taste?
to my mouth more then honie they.
I from thy precepts wisdome learne:
therefore I hate each lying way.

LG.HEAD: (14) Nun.
LG.L: Of my feet is thy word the lamp:
and to my path the shining light.
Sworne have I, & will it performe,
that I will keep thy judgements right.
I am afflicted very much:
Lord quicken mee after thy word.
Accept my mouths free-offrings now:
& mee thy judgements teach o Lord.
My soule is alwaies in my hand:
but I have not thy law forgot.
The wicked laide for mee a snare:
yet from thy laws I strayed not.
Thy recods are mine heritage
for aye: for my hearts joy they bee.
I bent my heart still to performe
thy sttues to eternitee.

LG.HEAD: (15) Samech.
LG.L: Pursue-I doe with hatred, all
vaine thoughts: but love thy law doe I.
My covert & my shield art thou:
I on thy word wait hopefully.
Depart from mee, lewd men, that I
may keepe my Gods commandements.
By thy word stay mee, & I live:
nor shame mee for my confidence.
Susteine mee, & I shall be safe:
and in thy law still I'le delight.
thou tread'st downe all that from thy laws
doe stray: for false is their deceit.
All th'earths lewd ones lke drosse thou-stroyd'st
therefore thy records love I do.
For feare of thee my flesh doth quake:
I doe thy judgements dread also.

LG.HEAD: (16) Hajin.
LG.L: Quite to oppressors leave mee not:
I judgement doe, & righteousnes.
thy servants suretie be for good:
let not the proud ones mee oppress.
Mine eyes for thy salvation faile:
as also for thy righteous word.
In mercie with thy servant deale:
& thy lawes-learning mee afford.
I am thy servant, make mee wise,
thy testimonies for to know.
Time for thee Lord it is to work,
for men thy law doe overthrow.
Therefore doe I thy precepts love,
above gold, yea the finest gold.
All false paths hate I: for thy rules
of all things, are all right, I hold.

LG.HEAD: (17) Pe·
LG.L: Right-wondrous are thy testimonies:
therefore my soule keeps them with care.
The entrance'of thy words gives light:
and makes them wise that simple are.
I gape & pant for thy precepts;
because I longed for the same.
Look on mee, & such grace mee show,
as thou dost them that love thy Name.
My steps by thy word guide: & let
no wickednes beare rule in mee.
From mens oppression mee redeem:
and thy laws-keeper will I bee.
Make thy face on thy servat shine:
and mee to learne thy statutes cause.
Mine eies run floods of waters downe:
because they doe not keep thy laws.

LG.HEAD: (18) Tade.
LG.L: Sincerely-just art thou, o Lord,
thy judgements upright are also.
Thy testimonies thou commandst
are right, yea, very faithfull too.
My zeale consumed mee, because
mine enemies thy words forget.
Thy word it is exceeding pure:
therefore thy servant loveth it.
Small am I, & contemptible:
yet thy commands forget not I.
Thy justice, justice is for aye:
also thy law is verity.
Distresse & anguish seas'd on mee:
yet thy commands delights mee give.
Thy records justice lasts for aye:
make thou mee wise, & I shall live.

LG.HEAD: (19) Koph.
LG.L: To mee that cry with my whole heart
Lord heare: thy statutes keep I will.
I unto thee did cry: save mee,
& I shall keep thy records still.
The dawning I prevent, & cry:
I for thy word doe hopefull-waie.
Mine eyes prevent the night-watches,
in thy word for to meditate.
Lord, of thy mercy heare my voice:
after thy judgements quicken mee.
Who follow mischiefe, they draw nigh:
who from thy law afarre off bee.
But o Iehovah, thou art neere:
and all thy precepts verity.
I long since of thy records knew:
thou laid'st them for eternity.

LG.HEAD: (20) esch.
LG.L: View mine affliction, & mee free:
for I thy law doe not forget.
Plead thou my cause, & mee redeem:
for thy words sake alive mee set.
Salvation from lewd men is far:
sith they thy laws to finde ne're strive.
Great are thy bowell-mercies Lord:
after thy judgements mee revive.
Many my foes and hunters are:
yet I not from thy records swerve.
I saw transgressors, & was griev'd,
for they thy word doe not observe.
See Lord, that I thy precepts love:
graunt, of thy bounty live I may.
Thy word's beginning it is truth:
and all thy right judgements for aye.

LG.HEAD: (21) Schin.
LG.L: Without cause Princes mee pursue:
but of thy word my hearts in awe.
As one that hath much booty found,
so I rejoyce doe in thy law.
Lying I hate, & it abhorre:
but thy law dearly love doe I.
Seven times a day I prayse thee, for
the judgements of thine equity.
Great peace have they that love thy law:
& such shall finde no stumbling-stone.
I hop't for thy salvation, Lord:
and thy commandments I have done.
My soule thy testimonies keeps:
and them I love exceedinglee.
I keep thy rules & thy records:
for all my waies before thee bee.

LG.HEAD: (22) Thau.
LG.L: Yield Lord, my cry, t'approach thy face:
as thou hast spoke, mee prudent make.
Let my request before thee come:
deliver mee for thy words sake.
My lips shall utter forth thy prayse:
when thou thy lawes hast learned mee.
My tongue shall forth thy word resound:
for all thy precepts justice bee.
To help mee let thy hand be neere:
for thy commandments chose have I.
I long for thy salvation, Lord:
and my delights in thy law ly.
Let my soule live, & shew thy prayse:
help mee also thy judgements let.
Like lost sheep strayd, thy servant seeke:
for I thy laws doe not forget

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 120. A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: VNto the Lord, in my distresse
o Lord, my soule set free.
What shall thy false tongue give to thee,
Sharp arrows of the mighty ones,
Woe's mee, that I in Mesech doe
that I doe dwell in tents, which doe
Long time my soule hath dwelt with him
I am for peace, but when I speake,

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 121. A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: I To the hills lift up mine eyes,
from whence shall come mine aid.
Mine help doth from Iehovah come,
Hee will not let thy foot be mov'd,
The Lord thy keeper is, the Lord
on thy right hand the shade.
The Sun by day, nor Moone by night,
The Lord will keep the from all ill:

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 122. A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: I Ioy'd in them, that to mee sayd
to the Lords house go wee.
Whether the tribes, Gods tribes ascend
For there the judgements thrones, the thrones
see that yee pray for it:
Prosper they shall that doe thee love.
For my brethren & for my friends,
I'le now speake peace to thee.
I'le for our God Iehovahs house,

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 123. A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: O Thou that sittest in the heav'ns,
I lift mine eyes to thee.
Loe, as the servants eyes unto
As maides eyes to her mistresse hand,
the Lord our God, untill that hee
O Lord be mercifull to us,
With scorne of those that be at ease,
also of those that great ones are,

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 124. A song of degrees▪ of David.
DIV2.L: HAd not the Lord been on our side,
Had not God been for us, when men
They had then swallow'd us alive,
when their wrath on us burn'd.
Then had the waters us o'rewhelmd,
the streame our soule or'e turnd.
The proud waters then, on our soule
Blest be the Lord, that to their teeth
did not give us a prey.
The succour which wee doe injoye,
wh is the maker of the earth,

DIV2.HEAD: psalme 125. A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: THey that doe in Iehovah trust
which cannot be remo'vd, but shall
Like as the mountaines round about
so doth the Lord surround his folk,
For lewd mens rod on just mens lot
lest just men should put forth their hand
To those Iehovah, that be good,
as also unto them that are
But who turne to their crooked wayes,
the Lord shall make them go

DIV2.HEAD: psalme 126. A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: WHen as the Lord return'd againe
at that time unto them that dreame
Then was our mouth with laughter fill'd,
the Lord hath done great things for them
The Lord hath done great things for us▪
As streames in South, doe thou o Lord,
Who sow in teares, shall reape in joy.
bearing choise seed, shall sure with joye

DIV2.HEAD: psalme 127. A song of degrees for Solomon.
DIV2.L: IF God build not the house, vainly
who build it doe take paine:
except the Lord the citty keepe,
I'ts vaine for you early to rise,
the bread of grief: so hee gives sleep
Loe, the wombes fruit, it's Gods reward
As arrows in a strong mans hand,
O blessed is the man which hath
they shall not be asham'd, i'th gate
when they speake with their foes.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 128. A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: For thou shalt eate with cheare
shall be by thine house side:
all thy lifes dayes that bee.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 129. A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: FRom my youth, now may Isr'ell say,
They mee assaild oft from my youth▪
The ploughers plough'd upon my back,
The righteous Lord the wickeds cords
Lt all that Sion hate be sham'd,
As grasse on houe tops, let them be,
which ere it's rown, doth wither:
Wherof that which might fill his hand
not therewith hee his bosome fills
that doth the sheaves up binde.
Neither doe they that passe by, say,
on you: you in Iehovahs Name

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 130. A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: LORD, from the depth I cryde to thee.
My voice Lord, doe thou heare:
Lord, who should stand? if thou o Lord,
But with thee there forgivenes is:
I for the Lord wayt, my soule wayts:
Then morning watchers watch for morn,
more my soule for the Lord.
In God hope Isr'ell, for mercy
is with the Lord: with him
there's much redemption. From all's sin

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 131. A song of degrees, of David.
DIV2.L: in thigs too great, or high for mee,
like as a child that weaned is,

DIV2.HEAD:
Psalme 132.
A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: How to the Lord he swore, & vow'd
upon the pallate of my bed,
nor will I give to mine eye-lidds
I doe finde out a seate:
there did wee of it heare:
ev'n in the plain-fields of the wood▪
wee found it to be there.
Arise, Lord, thou into thy rest:
and th'Arke of thy strength now.
Grant tha thy priests may be
o let thy holy ones likewis
Let not for Davids sake a part▪
the face of thine annoynted one
truth, nor will turne from it;
thy bodyes fruit, of them I'le make
If thy sons keep my law,
he hath desired it to bee
here will I dwell, and that because
the poore that be in her with bread
by mee all have their fill.
her holy ones likewse they shall
will make to bud forth there:

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 133. A song of degrees, of David

LG.L: HOw good and sweet o see,
i'ts for brethren to dwell
together in unitee:
It's like choise oyle that fell
the head upon,
that downe did flow
the beard unto,
beard of Aron:
The skirts of his garment
that unto them went downe;
ike Hermons dews descent,
Sions mountaines upon,
for there to bee
the Lords blessing,
life aye lasting
commandeth hee.

LG.HEAD: Annother of the same.
LG.L: HOw good it is, o see,
and how it pleaseth well,
together ev'n in unitee
for brethren soe to dwell:
I'ts like the choise oyntment
from head, to'th beard did go,
downe Arons beard: downeward that went
his garments skirts unto.
As Hermons dew, which did
on Sions hill descend:
for there the Lord blessing doth bid,
ev'n life without an end.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 134. A song of degrees.
DIV2.L: O All yee servants of the ord,
Lift up your hands, and blesse the Lord,
The Lord that heav'n & earth hath made,

LG.L: THe Lord praise, praise ye the Lords Name▪
the Lords servants o praise him yee.
That in the Lords house stand: the same
i'th Courts of our Gods house who bee.
The Lord prayse, for the Lord is good▪
for sweet its to his Name to sing.
For Iacob to him chose hath God:
& Isr'ell for his pretious thing,
For that the Lord is great I know:
& over all gods, our Lord keeps.
All that he wills, the Lord doth do:
in heav'n, earth, seas, & in all deeps.
The vapours he doth them constraine,
forth from the ends of th'earth to rise;
he maketh lightning for the raine:
the winde brings from his treasuries.
Of Egipt he the first borne smit:
and that o man, of beasts also.
Sent wondrous signs mist thee, Egipt:
on Pharoah, on all's servants too.
Who smote great natiōs, sew great Kings:
Sew Sihon King of th'Amorites,
Og also one of aīhans kings:
all kingdomes of the Cananites,
An gave their land an heritage:
his people Isr'ells lot to fall.
For aye thy Name, Lord, through each age
o Lord, is thy memoriall.
For his fols judge, the Lord is hee:
and of his servants he'le repent.
The hehens Idols silver bee,
& gold: mens hands did them invent.
Mouths have they, yet hey never spak▪
eyes have they, but they doe not see:
Eares have they, but no hearing take:
& in hir mouth no breathings bee.
They that them mke, have their likenes:
that trust in them so is each one.
The Lord o house of Isr'ell bless;
the Lord blesse, thou house of Aaron.
O house of Levi, blesse the Lord:
who feare the Lord, blesse ye the Lord.
From Sion blesse be the Lord;
who dwells at Salem praise the Lord.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 136.
DIV2.L: O Thank the Lord, for hee is good:
Give thanks unto the God of gods:
Give thanks unto the Lord of lords:
To him who only doth great signes:
To him whose wisdome made the heav'ns:
Who o're the waters spread the earth:
Vnto him that did make great lights:
The Sun for ruling of the day:
The Moone and Stars to rule by night:
To him who Egipts first-borne smote:
And from amongst them Isr'ell brought:
With strong hand, & with stretcht-out arme:
To him who did the red sea part:
And through i'ts midst made Isr'ell go:
But there dround Phroh & his hoast:
His people who through desart led:
To him which did smite mighty Kings:
And put to slaughter famous Kigs:
And Og who was of Bashan King:
And gave their land an eritage:
A lot his servant Israell to:
In our low 'state who minded us:
And us redeemed from or foes:
Who giveth food unto all flesh:
Vnto the God of heav'n give thanks:

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 137.
DIV2.L: there when wee did sit downe:
yea even then wee mourned, when
Our Harps wee did hang it amid,
Because there they that us away
Requir'd of us a song, & thus
askt mirth: us waste who laid,
sing us among a Sions song,
The lords song sing can wee? being
loose her skill my right hand, if I
Let cleave my tongue my pallate on,
if minde thee doe not I:
if chiefe joyes or'e I prize not more
it rase, it rase, when as it was
Blest shall hee bee, that payeth thee,
who must be waste: that which thou hast
O happie hee shall surely bee
thy little ones against the stones

LG.L: WIthall my heart, I'le prayse thee new:
before the gods I'le sing to thee.
Toward thine holy Temple bow,
& praise thy Name for thy mercee,
& thy truth: for thy word thou hye
or'e all thy Name dost magnify.
It'h day I cride, thou answredst mee:
with strength thou didst my soule up-beare.
Lord, all the earths kings shall praise thee,
the word when of thy mouth they heare.
Yea, they shall sing in the Lords wayes,
for great's Iehovahs glorious prayse.
Albeit that the Lord be hye,
respect yet hath he to the low:
but as for them that are lofty,
he them doth at a distance know·
Though in the midst I walking bee
of trouble thou wilt quicken mee,
Forth shalt thou make thine hand to go
against their wrath that doe me ,
thy right hand shall me save also.
The Lord will perfect mine estate:
thy mercy Lord, for ever stands:
leave not the works of thine owne hands.

LG.HEAD: Annother of the same.
LG.L: WIthall my heart, I'le thee confess:
thee praise the gods before.
The Temple of thine holines
towards it I'le adore:
Also I will confesse thy Name,
for thy truth, & mercy:
because thou over all thy Name
thy word dost magnify.
In that same day that I did cry,
thou didst mee answer make:
thou strengthnedst mee with strength, which I
within my soule did tak.
O Lord, when thy mouths words they heare
all earths Kings shall thee praise.
And for the Lords great glory, there
they shall sing in his wayes.
Albeit that the Lord be high,
yet hee respects the low:
but as for them that are lofty
hee them far off doth know.
Though I in midst of trouble go,
thee quickning mee I haue:
thy hand thou wilt cast on my foe,
thy right hand shall mee save.
The Lord will perfect it for mee:
thy mercy ever stands,
Lord, doe not those forsake that bee
the works of thine owne hands.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 139. To the chief musician, a psalme of David.

LG.L: O LORD, thou hast me searcht & knowne.
Thou knowst my sitting downe,
& mine up-rising: my thought is
to thee afarre off knowne.
Thou knowst my paths, & lying downe,
& all my ways knowst well·
For loe, each word that's in my tongue,
Lord, thou canst fully tell.
Behinde thou gird'st mee, & before:
& layst on mee thine hand.
Such knowledge is too strange, too high,
for mee to uderstand
Where shall I from thy presence go?
or where from thy face flye?
If heav'n I climbe, thou there, loe thou,
if downe in hell I lye.
If I take mornings wigs; & dwell
where umost sea-costs bee.
Ev'n there thy hand shall mee conduct▪
& thy right hand hold mee.
That veryly the darknes shall
mee cover, if I say:
then shall the night abou mee be
like to the lightsome day.
Yea, darkns hideth not from thee,
but as the day shines night:
alike unto hee both these are,
the darknes & the light.
Because that thou possssed hast
my reines: and covered mee
within my mothers wombe thou hst.
My prayse shall be of thee,
Because that I am fashiond
in fearull wondrous wise:
& that thy works are merveilous,
my soule right well descries.
From thee my substance was not hid,
when made I was closely:
& when within th'earths lowest par
I was wrought curiously.
Thine eyes upon my substance yet
imperfected, did look,
& all the mebers that I have
were written in thy booke,
What dayes they should be fashioned:
none of them yet were come.
How pretious are thy thoughts to mee,
o God? how great's their summe?
If I should count them, in number
more then the sands they bee:
& at what time I doe awake,
still I abide with thee.
Assuredly thou wilt o God,
those that be wicked slay:
yee that are bloody men, therefore
depart from mee away.
Because that they against thee doe
speake wickedly likewise:
thy Name doe take up in vaine
who are ine enemies.
Thy haers ord, doe I not hate?
& am not I with those
offended grievously that doe
up-rising thee oppose?
Them I with perfect hared hate:
I count them as my foes.
Search mee o God, & know my heart:
try mee, my thoughts disclose:
And see if any wicked way
in mee there bee at all:
& mee conduct within the way
that last for ever shall.

DIV2.HEAD:
Palme 140
To the chief musician, a psalme of David,

LG.L: LORD, free mee from the evill man:
from violent man save mee▪
Whose hearts thinke mischief: evry day
for war they gathred bee.
Their tongues they have made to be sharp
a serpent like unto:
the poyson of the Aspe it is
under their lipps also. Selah.
Keepe mee, Lord, from the wickeds hands,
from violent man mee save:
my goings who to overthrow
in thought projected have.
The proud have hid a snare for mee,
cords also: they a net
have spred abroad by the way side:
grins for mee they have set. Selah.
Vnto Iehovah I did say,
thou art a God to mee:
Lord, heare the voice of my requests,
which are for grace to thee.
O God, the Lord, who art the stay
of my salvation:
my head by thee hath covered been
the day of battell on.
Those mens desires that wicked are,
Iehovah, doe not grant,
their wicked purpose furher not,
lest they themselves doe vaunt.
As for the head of them that mee
doe round about inclose,
o let the molestation
of their lips cover those.
Let burning coales upon them fall,
into the fire likewise
et them be cast, into deep pits,
that they no more may rise.
Let not i'th earth establisht bee
men of an evill tongue:
evill shall hunt to overthrow.
the man of violent wrong.
The afflicteds cause, the poore mans right,
I know God will maintaine:
Yea, just shall praise thy Name: th'upright
shall 'fore thy face remaine.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 141. A psalme of David.
DIV2.L: O GOD, my Lord, on thee I call,
doe thou make hast to mee:
and harken thou unto my voice▪
And let my pray'r directed be
and the up-lifting of my hands
Iehovah, oh that thou would'st set
as also of my lips with care
o doe thou keepe the dore.
Bow not my heart to evill things;
it shall be such a pretious oyle,
my head it shall not breake:
For yet my prayr's ev'n in their woes.
on rocks, then shall they heare my words,
for they are sweet to taste.
Like unto one who on the earth
ev'n so our bones at the graves mouth
But unto thee o God, the Lord
my soule o leave not destitute,
O doe thou keepe mee from the snare
which they have layd for mee;
& also from the grins of those
untill such time that I escape

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 142. Maschil of David, a prayer when he was in the cave.
DIV2.L: my sute for grace made I.
I did poure out before his face
before his face I did declare
O'rewhelm'd in mee when was my spirit,
then thou didst know my way:
I'th way I walkt, a snare for mee
On my right hand I lookt, & saw,
but no man would mee know,
all refuge faild mee: for my soule
Then to thee Lord, I cryde, & sayd,
& in the land of living ones
Because I am brought very low,
from my pursuers save thou mee,
That I thy Name may praise, my soule
when thou shalt mee reward, the just

LG.L: LORD, heare my prayr, give eare when I
doe supplicate to thee:
in thy truth, in thy righteousnes;
make answer unto mee.
And into judgement enter not
with him that serveth thee;
for in thy sight no man that lives
can justified bee.
For th'enemie hath pursude my soule,
my life to'th ground hath throwne:
& made mee dwell i'th dark like them
that dead are long agone.
Therefore my spirit is overwhelmd
perplexedly in mee:
my heart also within mee is
made desolate to bee.
I call to minde th ayes of old,
I medita on use
on all thy wo: upon the work
of thy hands I doe muse.
I doe unto thee
reach mine out-stretched hands:
so after thee my soule doth thirst
as doe the thristy lands. Selah.
Hast, Lord, heare mee, my spirit doth faile,
hide not thy face mee fro:
lest I become like one of them
that downe to pit doe go.
Let mee thy mercy heare i'th morne,
for I doe on thee stay,
wherin that I should walk cause mee
o understand the way:
For unto thee I lift my soule.
O Lord deliver mee
from all mine enemies; I doe lye
to hide my selfe with thee.
Because thou art my God, thy will
oh teach thou mee to doe,
thy spirit is good: of uprightnes
lead mee the land into·
Iehovah, mee o quicken thou
ev'n for thine owne Names sake;
And for thy righteousnes my soule
from out of trouble take.
Doe thou also mine enemies
cut off in thy mercy,
destroy them that afflict my soule:
for thy servant am I.
O Let Iehovah blessed be
who is my rock of might,
who doth instruct my hands to war,
and my fingers to fight.
My goodnes, fortresse, my hye towre,
& that doth set mee free:
my shield, my trust, which doth subdue
my people under mee.
Iehoah, what is man, that thou
knowledge of him dost take?
what is the son of man, that thou
account of him dost make?
Man's like to vanity: his dayes
passe like a shade away.
Lord, bow the heav'ns, come downe & touch
the mounts & smoake shall they.
Lightning cast forth, & scatter them:
thine arrows shoot, them out,
Thine hand o send thou from above,
doe thou redeeme mee out:
And rid mee from the waters great:
from hand of strangers brood:
Whose mouth speaks lyes, their right hand is
a right hand of falsehood.
O God, new songs I'le sing to thee:
upon the Psaltery,
and on ten stringed instrument
to thee sing praise will I.
It's hee that giveth unto Kings
safety victorious:
his servant David he doth save
from sword pernitious.
Rid mee from hand of strange children,
whose mouth speakes vanity:
& their right hand a right hand is
of lying filsity:
That like as plants which are growne up
in youth may be our sons;
our daughters pallace like may be
pollisht as corner stones:
Our garners full, affording store
of every sort of meates;
our cattell bringing thousands forth,
ten thousands in our streets:
Strong let our oxen bee to work,
that breaking in none bee
no going out: that so our streets
may from complaints bee free.
O blessed shall the people be
whose state is such as this:
o blessed shall the people be,
whose God Iehovah is.

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 145. Davids psalme of praise.
DIV2.L: MY God, o King, I'le thee extoll:
For ever will I praise thy Name;
Great is the Lord, most worthy praise:
Age unto age shall prise thy works:
I of thy glorious honour will
Also men of thy mighty works
and they shall with a shouting voice
The Lord is gracious, & hee is
The Lord is good to all: or'e all part (2)
All thy works shall praise thee, o Lord:
They▪le of thy kingdomes glory speake:
and talk of thy powre hye;
To make mens os his great acts know:
Thy Kingdome is a kingdome aye:
The Lord doth hold up all that fall:
All eyes wayt on thee, & their meat
In all his wayes the Lord is just:
Hee's neere to all that call on him:
in truth that on him call.
of those that doe him feare:
Hee will be safety unto them,
and when they cry he'le heare.
The Lord preserves each one of them
My mouth the prayses of the Lord
also all flesh his holy Name

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 146.
DIV2.L: THe Lord praise: praise (my soule) the Lord,
So long as I doe live
I'le praise the Lord; while that I am,
praise to my God I'le give.
Trust not in Princes; nor mans son
His breath goe's forth, to's earth he turnes,
his thoughts that day doe end.
Happie is hee that hath the God
Which heav'n, earth, sea▪ all i them made:
The Lord doth loose the prisoners.
the Lord ope's eyes of blinde,
the Lord doth aise the bowed downe;
the Lord to'th just is kinde.
but hee of them that wicked are
The Lord shall reigne for evermore,

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 147.
DIV2.L: PRayse yee the Lord, for it
to our God for it's sweet,
The broke in heart he heales:
hee calls them all by kinde.
The Lord sets up the low:
on Harp, our Gods praise sing.
when as they cry feeds then.
nor in the leggs of men.
For thy gates barres he stayes▪
in thee thy sons doth bless.
Gives snow like wool, spreds hee

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 148. Hallelujah.
DIV2.L: FRom heav'n o praise the Lord:
Yee heav'ns of heav'ns him praise:
The Lords Name let them praise:
for hee spake, made they were.
whirl windes his word which keepe.
His folks horne he lifts hye
the praise of all's Saints, ev'n

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 149.
DIV2.L: PRaise yee the Lord: unto the Lord
doe yee sing a new song:
in him who him hath made:
children of Sion in their King
o let them be full glad.
O let them with melodious flute
let them sing praises unto him
Let them the gracious Saints that be
& as they lye upon their beds
Let their mouths have Gods praise: their hand
On eathen vengeance, on the folk
Their kings with chaines, with yron bolts
To doe on them the judgement writ:

DIV2.HEAD: Psalme 150.
DIV2.L: PRaise yee the Lord. praise God
o praise him in the firmament
O praise him for his acts
that gives a sound so hye:
& doe yee praise him with the Harp,
prais'd by you let him bee.
upon the Cimalls praise yee him
which hye their sound doe raise.
the praises of the Lord set forth:
o doe yee praise the Lord.

DIV1.HEAD: An admonition to the Reader.
DIV1.P: THe verses of these psalmes may be redced to six kindes, the first wherof may be neere fourty common tunes; as they , out of our chief musicians, by Tho. Ravens∣croft.

The second kinde may be sung in three tunes as Ps▪ 5.50. & 7. in our english psalm books. The third. may be sung indifferently, as ps. the 51.100. & ten cōmandements, in our english psalme books. which three tunes aforsaid, comprehend almost all this whole book of psalmes ing tunes most familiar to us.
The fourth. as ps. 148. of which there are but a∣bout five.
The fift. as ps. 112. or the Pater noster, of which there are but two. viz. 85. & 138.
The sixt. as ps. 113. of which but one, viz. 115.

DIV1.HEAD: Faults escaped in printing.
DIV1.P: The rest, which have escaped through over∣sight, you may amend, as you finde them obvious.
